{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7020456/chilco-mountain-trail-14", "title": "Chilco Mountain Trail #14", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=47.905706,-116.513037", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7020456", "info-text": {"description": "Note that this is an out and back trail, not a loop. You can continue from the north peak to also visit the south peak. \r\n\nThis trail leaves the trailhead on the scant remains of an old logging road heading southwest. The trailhead is clearly marked, and there is a small parking area with room for 3-5 cars. Once you begin the ascent, the trail climbs rather briskly pretty much all the way to the peak. It does level out a bit just before the last ascent to the north peak.\r\n\nThe 360-degree views are awesome. There are the remains of an old fire tower strewn about at the top. \r\n\nFrom the top of North Chilco you have the option to head back to your car, making this about a 5 mile route. \r\n\nOr\r\nIf you want to visit South Chilco Peak, you can continue onward along the ridge line, dropping to Chilco Saddle and then climb back up to S. Chilco which will include views of Hayden, Coeur d' Alene and other surrounding lakes.\r\n\nContinuing further south past S. Chilco to the end of trail #14 will be roughly 7.5 miles. Mid to late summer the trip past S. Chilco is worth it if you enjoy huckleberries. \r\n\nFrom the end of trail #14 turn around and head back making this out and back route a solid 15 miles with some of the best view in Northern Idaho.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7078872/what-the-trail-looks-like-for-the-most-part-some-rockier-areas", "ratings": {"rating": 4.3, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 7.4, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [5650, 4151], "alt-change": [2000, 1848], "avg-grade": 10.0, "max-grade": 32.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7035464/independence-creek-22", "title": "Independence Creek #22", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=47.881962,-116.208455", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7035464", "info-text": {"description": "A trail through gorgeous North Idaho scenery. The trail follows and crisscrosses Independence Creek. Along Independence Creek there are about 14 stream crossings. \r\n\nThis is a classic creek hike with a gentle grade along the creek, but don't let this fool you into thinking it is an easy hike. There are lots of little ups along the way that don't really show on the profile. \r\n\nAbout 3/4 of the way, the trail will bear right up the hill and leave the creek. Another trail continues along the creek and is worth checking out. From here the trail will climb to the road on a moderate grade. The trail will end at the road.\r\n\nMake sure you are prepared for wet feet. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7035789/forest-service-trail-3016", "title": "Forest Service Trail 3016", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=47.620753,-116.531372", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7035789", "info-text": {"description": "Take the off ramp exit on top of 4th of July Pass. Take a right and follow the signs to the Parking Lot. The Parking lot has plenty of room for many cars and has a vault style bathroom.  This area has been designated as a Nordic Ski and Snowshoeing area. During the summer though, hikers, horseback riders and mountain bikers use these trails. \r\n\nThe hike starts on Forest Service Trail 3. The trailhead lies at the western end of the parking lot. \r\n\nThis part of the trail is very fast rolling and wide. It is an old decommissioned forest road that now has turned into some smooth singletrack down the center. There are a few little views of the surrounding mountains but mostly you'll be sight seeing in a beautiful, lush green forest that is quiet and peaceful. \r\n\nAlong the way you'll come across warming huts and a bathroom that are used during the winter for the nordic skiers and those who snowshoe. You'll climb and descend as you roll along this 5.7 mile trail section. \r\n\nYou'll know you are near the end of the trail when you come upon a large, A-framed warming hut labeled Ian's Eagle Hut. Pass the warming hut on the left and the trail continues up to the left about 30 feet pass the hut. The trail climbs sharply at this point using a couple of small switchbacks and it gets a little brushy. Continue up a little more and you'll pop out onto an old forest road. This forest road is Forest Road 1575 and will only show up on older maps. \r\n\nYou can go back the way you came exploring some of the other trails in the Nordic Ski Park or take a left and follow the forest roads to you vehicle.", "condition": "Minor Issues"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7036021/looking-west-on-forest-service-trail-3016", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 5.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3335, 2991], "alt-change": [740, 524], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 17.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7041221/hells-canyon-trail-trail-243", "title": "Hells Canyon Trail (Trail #243)", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=47.824751,-116.605717", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7041221", "info-text": {"description": "This is a newer trail opened 2014. The older trail was rerouted and brought up out of the valley floor to the southern hillside of the adjacent mountains. Deterioration and rutting was a common problem with the older trail, because of its location in the deep valley floor where lots of moisture sets in. The new trail is a welcome treat as it now allows users some brief views of the surrounding landscapes.\r\nThere is an Upper and Lower Trailhead. The Lower Trailhead has a developed parking lot. The Upper Trailhead is located at a wide road junction, with enough room to park a few vehicles.\r\n\nThe trail is a wide-based trail with an average width of approximately three feet. It is made up of dirt with a gravel/rock mixture. It is hard packed during the late spring/early summer season and loosens up a bit during the dryer months of August and September. There can be lots of snow fall in this area so trail use will depend upon the snow fall for that year.  Motorbikes frequent this area.\r\n\nStarting at the lower trailhead is the route of choice.  You can climb up to the Upper Trailhead by either climbing up the trail, or by climbing up Forest Road 437.  If you choose the Road, climb up 437 until you reach Hudlow Saddle. At Hudlow Saddle take a right onto Forest Road 406. Once at the Forest Road 406 /1511 junction look north (to the right) and you'll find the Upper 234 Trailhead.\r\n\nStarting from the Lower Trailhead, the trail crosses Hayden Creek and starts up the Hells Canyon drainage. It starts out as a good climb with a few switchbacks to get you started up the southern, sidehill slope. The trail weaves in and out of small drainages and up and around many ridges. You'll get some good views of the Hells Canyon drainage on this trail which is a huge bonus compared to the older trail.\r\n\nIt only takes about 40 minutes from the city of Coeur d' Alene to get the the Lower Trailhead. Have some fun exploring this North Idaho backcountry trail!", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 4.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [4177, 2643], "alt-change": [1577, 43], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 20.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7093323/indian-cliffs-trail", "title": "Indian Cliffs Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=47.360417,-116.779648", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7093323", "info-text": {"description": "Park at the Indian Cliffs parking area, paying the parking fee, and start up the trail near the parking lot entrance (the trail at the back is a fire trail, not the hiking trail.) Continue through the trees to where the trail splits, immediately after a small plank bridge over an idyllic stream. Take either branch, as both will lead to the top of the cliffs. \r\n\nThe trail winds up with moderate inclines, passing trees and rocks, to the top of the cliffs, where you'll find a beautiful view over the south end of Lake Coeur d'Alene, known as Chatcolet Lake. If you look south across the lake, you'll see old iron railroad trestles cutting through the hills, which are still in use. Looking east will bring you a view of where the Saint Joe River far out into the lake through a channel grown thick with willows and cotton woods, where it finally ends in the middle of the lake.", "features": "Geological Significance \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Minor Issues"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7070032/chatcolet-lake-looking-east-to-saint-joe-river", "ratings": {"rating": 4.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 2.8, "dist-type": "Lollipop", "alt-range": [2687, 2203], "alt-change": [507, 506], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 24.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7031014/gunpowder-ridge", "title": "Gunpowder Ridge", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=46.363742,-117.057084", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7031014", "info-text": {"description": "Located a few miles up the Snake River from Lewiston, this short trail is part of Hells Gate State Park trail system. It is mostly singletrack up a mellow ridge through tall grasses and wildflowers.  \r\n\nIt starts out on the north end with two moderately steep switchbacks before leveling out for the remainder of the ridge where it meets up with Easy Street Trail at Saddleback Point, which offers great views of the Snake River which borders the park and the small town of Asotin across the way. It can be taken in either direction or combined with several other trails to make different loops.\r\n\nIf accessed from Hells Gate State Park, this is a fee area and requires the purchase of a day pass or an Idaho State Parks pass. It can also be accessed from a free parking lot on Tammany Creek Rd just east of Saddleback Point. This is a well-maintained parking lot with signage. There are restrooms located in the park camping/picnic areas or at this parking lot.\r\n\nThis area is frequented by other hikers, cyclists, and equestrian riders so please hike responsibly. Spring and early summer are ideal. The grasses are lush and green and the wildflowers are in full bloom. Lewiston gets hot in the summer so hit the trail early as there is no shade outside of the campgrounds. The park is home to rattlesnakes and bull snakes especially in areas near the water.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.8, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [960, 803], "alt-change": [157, 3], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 10.0}},

After a short and easy climb through the woods the trail breaks open into a large meadow where it starts angling down. Stick to this trail, heading south, down the Crystal Springs drainage. About halfway down the creek will be crystal clear from springs bubbling up. Eventually the trail forks where a tributary drainage comes in from the west. Bear left up a short steep climb. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7086000/mt-jefferson", "title": "Mt. There is a pullout parking lot at the trailhead to the south (left) of the dirt road. The trailhead is on the west side of where the Forest Service signage is at.\r\n\nA majority of this trail skirts along the Idaho/Montana border. It offers fantastic views into both states. Follow the Sawtell Peak #165 trail to start; this trail is well-marked until you need to split off after 2.3 miles. It will pop you up to sidehills and ridgelines the rest of the way. \r\n\nThe trail is poorly marked where you turn. Pretty much non-existent and you'll only know when to turn by following the GPX track or Forest Service map. You'll find the trail in spots, along with multiple Idaho/Wyoming land survey markers. You can park in the West Fork parking lot and hike down the road about 100 meters and take a right to head up Valve House. \r\n\nThe trails starts out as open, sage ensconced doubletrack and slowly becomes more forested as you gain altitude. The first four miles is a fairly steady climb with a few technical sections. The trail then begins to descend after the second cattle guard you encounter. Directly after this guard you'll encounter Windago on your right. Valve House also connects to Blind Springs in a couple of places.\r\n\nThe trail can be rocky, rutted and has a few steep, but manageable grades. Even though it is a doubletrack, descending this trail feels like singletrack. Additionally, you may encounter wildlife, as the area is full of it. It also hosts cow grazing and all the glory that comes along with that!", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7083235/a-beautiful-stream-inundates-the-valve-house-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 3.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 6.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [7071, 5202], "alt-change": [2034, 166], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 33.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7040847/south-fork-inman-creek-canyon-trail", "title": "South Fork Inman Creek Canyon Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.80595,-112.126241", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7040847", "info-text": {"description": "If you hike down from the top, it will be all downhill except for about 150 yards at the beginning. One can take a truck up the Inman Road to the field at the top fairly easily, it's about a 45 minute drive. It is fairly steep, so going downhill will require some decent brakes. \r\nAs for obstacles, it varies depending on how much the runoff of the year affected the trail, usually there are some rocky sections to drop down over and lots of roots. The bridge at the bottom of the canyon is in pretty bad shape. \r\n\nThere are a few times that the trail crosses the creek in the bottom of the canyon, and while some are not too bad (again it depends on the year), you might get pretty wet going over some of them. The few bridges that cross it are in good shape, even though there are sometimes trails that don't follow them.\r\n\nOverall this is a fairly easy trail, one that goes through some beautiful country, and truly is pretty well maintained. Expect to see dirt bikers, hikers, bikers, and there are a lot of hunters in this area during hunting season, so be courteous.\r\n\nNote: The area has open grazing for cows", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 3.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [7222, 6085], "alt-change": [165, 1160], "avg-grade": 8.0, "max-grade": 25.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7103194/north-boundary-trail-244-boundary-trail-072", "title": "North Boundary Trail #244 (Boundary Trail 072)", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.779859,-112.163539", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7103194", "info-text": {"description": "This trail has a few places where you can start: Pebble Creek Ski Area, Inkom Pass (via South Fork Inman Creek Canyon Trail and the Upper Jackson Creek Trail), or Big Springs Campground. The trail follows a wider track that accommodates ATVs and dirt bikes. From Pebble Creek Ski Area, the trail heads north until it crosses Jackson Creek. The trail then heads up Jackson Creek Canyon to Inkom Pass. This is a steep climb, and will probably be difficult for most people to run, but hiking is okay. The footing here is rocky in many places. From Inkom Pass, the trail drops down towards Big Springs Campground in a nice gradual drop. This section is nice and shady, passing under a lovely canopy of pines, aspens, fir, and spruce trees.\r\n\nThe route has signs that say \"Boundary Trail 072\" throughout the route, but the USFS maps label this trail the North Boundary Trail and assign the number 244 to it.\r\n\nRoute breakdown going eastbound (start by heading north) from Pebble Creek Ski area to Big Springs Campground\r\n\n0: Pebble Creek Ski Area\r\n0.1: Green Canyon Creek crossing (bridge)\r\n0.8: Unnamed creek (easy crossing)\r\n1.9: Jackson Creek (easy crossing) 1300 foot climb after\r\n3.8: Inkom Pass (Junct. with Inkom Pass Loop #242 and Upper Jackson Creek Trail #243 \n4.4: Small creek crossing. There may be water here early in the season\r\n5.6 Small creek crossing\r\nAround 6: There is a series of deep muddy ponds in the road. They probably dry out by mid to late summer\r\n6.3: There is a tricky junction with a jeep road. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7103195/robbers-roost-trail-253", "title": "Robbers Roost Trail #253", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.762094,-112.092608", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7103195", "info-text": {"description": "This trail passes over the Portneuf Mountains through the saddle between Haystack Mountain and Bonneville Peak. This ridge is a geological marvel, with stunning bands of rocky cliffs abounding along the ridgeline. The trail is pretty steep and rocky, which makes for difficult hiking in many places. However, your hard work will be rewarded with great views. From the saddle, you can climb Haystack or Bonneville peak by going either south or north. You can then descend to the opposite side of the range or return from where you started. Either end provides you with an easy start. This route features numerous climbs over ridges and down into canyons. There is a diversity of plant life as you ascend up and down through different types of forests, from low elevation pinyon forests up through aspen groves and large pine and fir forests.\r\n\nEarly in the season, this route has many creek crossings. Later in the season, these creeks shrink considerably, and so there are fewer crossings. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7103369/west-fork-gibson-jack-015", "title": "West Fork Gibson Jack #015", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.792847,-112.431416", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7103369", "info-text": {"description": "This trail begins at the Gibson Jack trailhead. It is a wide ATV track meant for mixed-use, but specifically it provides a route for motorized vehicles to access the backcountry east of Pocatello. The trail is steep in some places, and can be quite rocky at times, but overall, it is a great trail for hiking and running. The high ridge portion is especially fun, and the evergreen forests are great. The trail splits off from the main Gibson Jack trail within tenth of a mile from the beginning of the trailhead. The trail then crosses Gibson Jack Creek via a very nice new bridge. It then immediately climbs up the ridgeline south of Gibson Jack Creek, then switches back to head east and continues its relentless ascent. Watch for the Slate Mountain Trail fork at the top of the first ridge you crest. Slate goes to the left, and this trail goes uphill, to the right. After you reach the apex, at about 7000 feet, you drop down into a lush riparian area in the upper West Fork basin. The trail ends at Elk Meadows Loop, which provides adventurers with many opportunities for exploring. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7104747/bell-marsh-walker-goodenough", "title": "Bell Marsh-Walker-Goodenough", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.654399,-112.285754", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7104747", "info-text": {"description": "This trail has two main access points: Goodenough Campground on the south side, and Walker Canyon on the north. Goodenough Campground is accessible by any vehicle. It is at the end of a well-maintained gravel road. Walker Canyon is a dirt road, a little rougher, and requires a some clearance. The trail is a nice, wide trail, used for a variety of travel methods, like foot, horses, bikes, and ATVs. Follow the signs for the Broken Top loop and exclaim joy when the pavement ends quickly and you are hiking through lava flows. Marvel at the otherworldly beauty of lava rock that cooled in ways that allow you to see the flow. Discuss what causes the iridescent sheen on some of the rocks with your friend, or yourself. I don't judge. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7097424/indian-tunnel-trail", "title": "Indian Tunnel Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.444253,-113.528538", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7097424", "info-text": {"description": "From the Caves Trail turn and head South at Dew Drop Cave. The first two caved in sections you come to are part of the Indian Tunnels lava tube but no longer connect without tight squeezes and a lot of crawling. \r\n\nAt the third opening, the paved trail ends at a steel stairway. You may need a flashlight if it is early or late in the day or overcast. Most people hike it without a flashlight and take it slow in the shadows. The trail heads South from opening to opening and is easily deciphered. I highly recommend checking out the two legs of the tunnel that head back North. \r\n\nBonus: At the bottom of the entry hole, if you go north in one or the other legs of the tunnel, there is a connecting crawl to cut over to the other leg just for fun.\r\n\nThe Trail runs roughly South with various skylights and over or around large piles of rubble on the floor. At times you'll be hiking on the frozen surface of a lava river. At the end of the tunnel, you are forced up and out a small hole but it is not a tight squeeze like it first looks.\r\n\nOnce on the surface again, head north always sighting in on the next marker pole. The trail back is undefined and overland style. Watch where you are going and for sure avoid the skylights and your last step! This section is not overly difficult but is has no improvements made to it (just how we like it) other than a post here and there. You should always be able to see the next post, if not, stop and re-evaluate your course. You should regain the paved path near the steel stairs.\r\n\nDue to the trail being partly a loop and partly out and back, the distance is listed incorrectly. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7083757/idaho-centennial-trail-section-4", "title": "Idaho Centennial Trail: Section 4", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.302621,-115.552163", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7083757", "info-text": {"description": "Following old ranching roads, this section of the ICT is fairly easy-going. Route-finding, however, can still be challenging, since there is a wide network of cattle paths, jeep trails, and other roads. Periodically, there are carbon fiber posts placed to reassure users that they are on the right track, but these are often vandalized over the years. It's best to come prepared with maps, coordinates, and GPS points. \r\n\nThis section passes by several dry lake beds, called the Inside Lakes. Visiting these lakes requires short detours from the trail. Another interesting feature is the Bengoechea Cabin, an abandoned sheepherders stone cabin from the early 1900s. This cabin is a short distance from the trail, and it serves as a significant landmark in an otherwise barren sea of sagebrush. \r\n\nA short distance from the cabin is a blast crater from a military test conducted in the 1960s. It is a large, deep crater. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7003575/sweet-connie", "title": "Sweet Connie", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.742775,-116.149696", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7003575", "info-text": {"description": "The start of this trail is off of the Stack Rock Trail at the large dead tree. If you see the Mr. Big turnoff, you've gone too far. The trail descends on steep and loose switchbacks to start until you get down into Daniels Creek. Once in the creek bottom, the trail weaves down the drainage. The trail can get very narrow in sections with a drop off into the creek. \r\n\nEventually, you'll come out on a jeep track. Follow the track for about 0.25 miles, then follow the trail marker to the left back onto the trail. \r\n\nFrom here, the trail avoids the steep descent and follows the switchbacks to take you to the bottom of the ravine. The trail then climbs to a flat and rocky section. Pass the trailhead to the Chukkar Butte Trail and continue downhill. Continue to stay left at any of the faint trails as you continue the descent. The final 0.5 miles ascend through a \"zen garden\" of granite boulders (where you'll break stride to clamber over the rocks). Finally, the trail will bear left and climb up to Bogus Basin Road. \r\n\nA permanent easement agreement was signed between the landowner and the City of Boise. The more rutted sections have been nicely repaired!", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7081541/at-the-end-of-the-trail-at-bogus-basin-road-looking-to-the-northwest-chukkar-but", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 6.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [5364, 3411], "alt-change": [354, 2004], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 19.0}},

As adventurers climb up the southern slopes of the Bennett Hills, they will be rewarded with an ever-expanding view of the Snake River Plain and the surrounding countryside, dotted with windmills, pivot-irrigated farmland, and ranch houses. Birds of prey soar overhead, while sparrows, wrens, and thrushes chirp throughout the surrounding sagebrush. \r\n\nThis area seems so removed from the world, yet a major interstate is just a few miles away. Water isn't common in this stretch, though the trail does cross Cold Springs Creek, which could have water in the spring. Most of this section is on a paved or improved gravel road, so the hiking is straightforward, if not a little monotonous.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 10.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3713, 3118], "alt-change": [673, 94], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 11.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7085778/idaho-centennial-trail-section-13", "title": "Idaho Centennial Trail: Section 13", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.211429,-115.343548", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7085778", "info-text": {"description": "This route continues along the Bennett Hills Road, a nice, wide dirt road. The surface is pretty soft, but good for hiking. The road follows Little Canyon Creek on the south side and Little Camas Creek on the north side. Both are nice streams that create lush, riparian habitats, full of vegetation and wildlife.\r\n\nThis area is a great spot for beavers, moose, deer, and elk. This section has a lot of private property on both sides of the road, so if you want to do any side excursions, make sure you are on public land. Stay off land marked private.\r\n\nOne incredible part of this section is that a local rancher has placed dozens of birdhouses on fence posts along the road. Numerous mountain bluebirds use these houses during their migration northward, and other birds use them during the summer and fall. It is a highlight of this section to see the hundreds of lovely songbirds that inhabit this area. \r\n\nThe trail eventually meets up with US 20 and follows the highway for a few miles. Use caution when crossing the highway and hiking alongside it. The shoulder is ample for hiking, but you never know when drivers are driving too fast around corners. Be aware of your surroundings.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Fishing \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 10.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [6144, 4992], "alt-change": [449, 1311], "avg-grade": 3.0, "max-grade": 11.0}},

Stay right and enjoy a spectacular rim view at 16 miles.\r\n\nAs you drop into Bruneau Canyon on the \"Indian Hot Springs Grade\" keep an eye out for cool bits of jasper. This canyon is often used in Airforce training missions. Watch for Birds of Prey and flowers in spring. On the way down be sure to stop for a picture at the old abandon pickup. At the bottom, you'll cross a sketchy bridge and possibly see some rafters floating the river headed for white water.\r\n\nOnce across the old wooden bridge be sure to visit the hot springs and the stone cabin for pictures and a much-deserved soak at the 18 mile mark.\r\n\nThe road then climbs up 2 miles to the West side of the canyon and another old stone cabin sitting right on the rim. From the Deer Point Trail, climb a number of switchbacks with some rock features along the way. You'll eventually leave the switchbacks, break out of the trees and be presented with amazing views across the mountains. On a clear day, you can see the Sawtooths off in the distance.\r\n\nFrom here the trail descends across some meadows and then back into the trees. There is one more brisk climb where trail traverses underneath Superior Lift and around the backside of the resort. The trail then comes to an end on an old cat track. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7036761/gardiner-peak-trail", "title": "Gardiner Peak Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.731391,-116.086886", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7036761", "info-text": {"description": "The Gardiner Peak Trail is mainly used to connect Mahalo to the Boise Ridge Road. This section is a very moderate climb, the trail is easy and only has a couple of roots. From the Ridge Road to the junction with Mahalo you'll see the most traffic; once you pass the intersection with Mahalo the trail gets more rugged. \r\n\nThere is a steep section up near the peak, after which you have a fun downhill. It is recommended to turn left onto Clear Creek Summit Trail as opposed to descending into Dagget Creek. There is no sign at the junction so please consult the map. \r\n\nBeyond the Clear Creek Summit Trail junction, the trail drops steeply into Dagget Creek. The descent is a little challenging, and once you get into the creek, you'll have a lot of creek hiking. There has been talk of re-routing the Dagget Creek section of this trail, but it has not happened yet.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 7.5, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [6460, 4836], "alt-change": [1485, 1882], "avg-grade": 9.0, "max-grade": 35.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7003571/eastside-trail", "title": "Eastside Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.761197,-116.107466", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7003571", "info-text": {"description": "The Eastside Trail is the main trunk trail in the Stack Rock trail system. It can be combined with many other trails to form a great adventure. The first part of the trail was constructed in 2003 and 2004 on mostly old logging roads from the 50s and 60s by mountain bikers.\r\n\nThe best place to start the trail is from Bogus Basin road. After leaving the road, you'll drop onto the XC ski trails for a little ways. You'll just need to make sure to stay left at any junction, but everything is signed well. Once off the XC ski trails, the trail will continue descending the mountain. At a viewpoint, a trail pops in from the left and then shortly afterwards Sinker Creek Trail peels off on the right. Follow the signs and stay on Eastside. The next junction will be a sharp turn at the DB connector. Turn left and continue down the trail all the way to the creek bottom at Sinker Creek. At this junction follow the signs across the creek and begin climbing out of the drainage. The Eastside Trail then terminates at the Stack Rock Trail.\r\n\nYou can park at the pullouts along the road or at the ski resort and then use the Stack Rock Trail to return to the road at the end of the trail. This trail is also used to connect to Sweet Sweet Coonie or to access Stack Rock. There are no bail out points that take you back to the road until the end of the trail, so please be prepared.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 6.5, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [6164, 5019], "alt-change": [626, 1400], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 20.0}},

The cliffs above the trail contain numerous bird life\u2014swallows, hawks, ravens, and more. The trail leads down to the river and an old bridge that used to be a main crossing of the Snake River in the area. Some people use this to access good fishing spots along the river. There are several paths that branch off the main trail, but it is easy to keep on the main path. The river is a little swift in places, but there are a few decent spots that one could swim in. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7090831/pillar-falls-trail", "title": "Pillar Falls Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.592113,-114.434596", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7090831", "info-text": {"description": "The trail begins off a dead end section along Pole Line Road. The former small parking area adjacent to trailhead is on private property and has been removed/closed. There is parking and portable toilets at the large lot at the corner of Pole Line and Eastland. This will add another half mile round trip to your hike, if you park here. Do not park in front of houses.  This is private property and the owners will be very upset.\r\n\nThe trail starts off by quickly losing elevation on a steep slope into the canyon. It switches back and forth several times alongside a drainage that usually has water flowing from spring into summer. In fall and winter, the flow is usually negligible. At peak flow, the stream is quite impressive.\r\n\nThe trail continues down toward the river. It levels out for a bit and forks. The left fork will take you down to a nice waterfall and pump station. The waterfall is impressive, especially in the spring. It turns into a trickle later on in the year. The right fork takes you over to Pillar Falls, which is an impressive series of rapids scattered among large pillar-like islands. The trail fades before getting down to the river, but it is still accessible if you are feeling adventurous. The area around the riverbanks is quite lush and magical. Unfortunately, previous visitors have left a lot of trash and debris behind. Sometimes people camp down here, which adds to the detritus. Still, it is a remarkable area, very much worth the visit.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fishing \u00b7 Geological Significance \u00b7 Historical Significance \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Swimming \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 0.5, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3627, 3203], "alt-change": [0, 424], "avg-grade": 16.0, "max-grade": 29.0}},

Once past the horse camp, you come to a dry marsh, most of the year, and briefly join the Equine Short Loop Trail for another dose of flies before branching off to the left at 1 mile. At about 1.5 miles you start to climb the biggest dune on a long ever steepening ridge. \r\n\nIt is only 2.5 miles to the summit but in the sand, you'll have done 4 miles by now. Take in the view and keep going along the ridge, down and around a large bowl, and up to the next peak at 3.25 miles (7 miles of sand). Now drop down to the lake and sneak through the trees. \r\n\nMost will opt for the Education Center Trail to get back sooner but this trail still has more sand to the north as you skirt the second lake and end up at the boat ramp. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7000006/wood-river-paved-path", "title": "Wood River Paved Path", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.718407,-114.378335", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7000006", "info-text": {"description": "This wide, smooth, paved multi-use path is part of the Wood River Trail System. It can be traveled in sections, in any direction, and is well marked with wooden signposts at each junction, making getting lost a near impossibility. Drivers are generally very courteous to path users, but use caution at the numerous crossings. Benches, water fountains, toilets and emergency phones are scattered along its length, making this path a user-friendly undertaking. \r\n\nIf done in the north to south (Ketchum to Hailey to Bellevue) direction, the path is a gentle downhill trek, and takes in the varied scenery of the Wood River Valley. Starting north at mile 0 (Hulen Meadows), enjoy listening to the rushing waters of the Big Wood River before dipping down through a lovely, fence-lined, wooded section. The hillside views open up and highway noises increase for several miles of travel along a tree-lined stretch into Ketchum. Pass through the industrial northern reaches of Ketchum, skirting downtown to the west and finally through a quieter, residential part of town. Numerous feeder paths from neighborhoods join the main Wood River Trail throughout its entirety. \r\n\nAfter two tunnels near mile 5 and a detour behind St. Luke's Hospital, the path enters a peaceful wooded area where huge mansions are tucked in the trees. Interpretive signs at the Trestle Bridge, Railroad Bridges, and Boxcar Bend offer informative history lessons and benches give an excuse to take a rest. Around mile 9, the valley widens and trees recede, making the path sunny and more exposed. Keep an eye out for the interesting representation of the solar system painted on the western edge of the path- the sun and planets are shown sized to scale with relative distances from the sun measured out. \r\n\nThe Wood River path leaves Highway 75 and parallels Buttercup Road past the Valley Club golf course, hay fields and ranches on its approach to Hailey. At about mile 14, the path traverses the town of Hailey on 5th Avenue and passes the airport before leaving town. The remainder of the path to Bellevue is not as pleasant due to its proximity to the highway, but it gets points for agricultural splendor.  Note: bikes are allowed on this trail.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7000039/users-of-all-ages-enjoy-the-wood-river-paved-path", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 21.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [5932, 5158], "alt-change": [50, 824], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 3.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7000007/elkhorn-road-paved-path", "title": "Elkhorn Road Paved Path", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.692588,-114.367825", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7000007", "info-text": {"description": "This paved multi-use path is part of the Wood River Trail System. It can be done in sections, in any direction, and is well marked with wooden signposts at each junction, making getting lost a near impossibility.  From the junction of Highway 75 and Saddle Road, the path begins with a mildly steep ascent paralleling the heavy car traffic on Saddle Road. Although walkers should beware of cars pulling out of side streets, residents are patient and very courteous to path users.  \r\n\nContinue from Saddle Road straight ahead on Dollar Road and pass the picturesque Sun Valley Lake. Use caution at the right-hand crossing onto Elkhorn Road. The gradual hill that climbs next to the Dollar Mountain ski slopes and the Elkhorn Golf Course is the main challenge on this path, but the views along the way are spectacular.   Upon reaching the top, enjoy a scenic descent down to the junction of Elkhorn Road and Morning Star Road. \r\n\nFor a shorter, more level walk: continue straight on Elkhorn Road. To add a 150 foot hill over 1.75 miles, take a left on Morning Star Road for a bonus jaunt on this quiet residential road before rejoining Elkhorn Road.  Prepare yourself for the most enjoyable part of this path as it leaves the neighborhoods behind and descends the gentle Elkhorn Gulch wetland area. The path crosses bridges and alternately meanders through open fields and groves of trees. Pass through a tunnel under Highway 75 to join the Wood River Trail System. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7026566/huckleberry-trail", "title": "Huckleberry Trail", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.927163,-116.075064", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7026566", "info-text": {"description": "The Huckleberry Trail runs along the eastern side of Ponderosa State Park, with a couple of great places to get into the lake to cool off. It's open to mountain bikers, but it is not ridden very much. True to its name, there are plenty of huckleberries when they are in season.\r\n\nYou can pick up this trail in several places, but this route starts on southeast edge of the park along the sandy trail by the big tree. The trail wanders through the big ponderosa pines, over a few small rolling hills, follows a doubletrack for a short while, and then goes back to singletrack. The trail crosses a closed road and after a minute or two you'll start to see the lake. The trail drops down to the water's edge at a sandy beach, perfect for a swim or playing fetch with the dog.  There are great view of Boulder and Jughandle Mountains from here too. There's even a bench if you want to sit for longer.\r\n\nThe trail continues on the lake edge for a few hundred feet and then goes back into the trees. You'll go by Huckleberry Bay and if you want to cut the hike short, turn left and take the road back. Stay on the trail and head out toward the point.  There is a good climb, but it is short (0.2 miles). Soon the trail leaves the trees and enters an open meadow. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7034967/two-dog", "title": "Two Dog", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.490953,-114.392286", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7034967", "info-text": {"description": "Two Dog is the longest trail in the Croy Creek trail system and connects Bullion Gulch with the Croy Creek Valley.\r\n\nFrom Bullion Gulch Road, start a long and steady climb up a large dry hillside through a series of switchbacks into a big drainage. The trail straightens out for a short time and then in and out of a small gully, before resuming the contouring climb up the north side on a long stretch of singletrack. \r\n\nThe route turns right, around the head of the valley, and proceeds through one more steep-ish turn before reaching the high point - a saddle that overlooks a large dry valley with rugged peaks in the distance.\r\n\nFrom here, Two Dog begins the first part of its longest descent on rolling, exposed trail across a steep hillside. As you finish this section and round the base of the hill, the view opens up into the main part of the trails system and the Croy Creek valley.\r\n\nThe end of this descent you'll go through a series of bermed turns and around a knoll to an intersection with  Centerline. Continue straight on a quick level section that transitions to a mellow downhill section that winds its way to the south. \r\n\nHike a bit uphill before the intersection with Wilson Gulch and then enjoy another downhill section along a draining. You'll see the Wilson Gulch singletrack up on the opposite hillside.\r\n\nThe trail starts going uphill again at Nadya's Connector and then continues climbing gradually to the end where it intersects with Bullion Connector Trail.", "features": "Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 6.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [6414, 5531], "alt-change": [826, 1062], "avg-grade": 5.0, "max-grade": 14.0}},

You'll pass the 20-Mile Lake Trail on your right which branches off 3 miles from the 20-Mile Trailhead.  \r\n\nThis trail takes you through old burns, avalanche debris and a beautiful glaciated canyon. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7016703/hum-lake-north-fork-lick-creek-trail-082", "title": "Hum Lake / North Fork Lick Creek Trail #082", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.053951,-115.932618", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7016703", "info-text": {"description": "This trail takes you up a well-maintained track to the Hum Lake Trail junction just before you get to Duck Lake. You then climb up through a burn from 1994 which provides unlimited views of the surrounding peaks. You climb continually until you reach the saddle above Hum Lake. You can turn around here or continue on down to Hum Lake.\r\n\nThe trail beyond Hum Lake continues up the ridge and through another pass to the North Fork of Lick Creek. This portion of the trail has not been maintained in several years and has a lot of blowdown, brush and lost sections of trail. If you try to tackle this portion, you can continue down the North Fork of Lick Creek to its junction with Split Creek Trail and continue out to Lick Creek Road. This is a good place to shuttle a vehicle too so you don't have to do an out and back. This portion from Hum Lake to Split Creek is very difficult and good route finding skills are a must. Use the Hiking Project mobile app to help find your way.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Swimming \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7014428/idaho-trails-association-volunteers-cutting-logs-out-of-the-hum-lake-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 3.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 11.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [8028, 4597], "alt-change": [2488, 4715], "avg-grade": 12.0, "max-grade": 61.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7025315/east-fork-lake-fork-trail-104", "title": "East Fork Lake Fork Trail #104", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.998841,-115.947063", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7025315", "info-text": {"description": "Start at the Snowslide Trailhead (Forest Service Trail #104) on Lick Creek Road, there is a small parking area at the trailhead. Step across the creek, and the climbing starts about a 1/10 of mile after trailhead. It gets steep quickly, but don't turn around, the views are worth the effort. Watch your footing in the steep sections; there are some loose gravel/rock spots in the first mile. \r\n\nAt 1.5 miles, Snowslide Lake will come into view. There are a couple of dispersed campsites beside the lake. The trail starts to pull away from the lake after the campsites. The half mile to the summit is steep. Again, watch your footing as you get near the summit. There are some great views from the summit (8,141') and you can scramble to Sawtooth Peak (8,875') or Snowslide Peak (8,522') from here. \r\n\nThe trail off the backside of the summit is not obvious, but with your back to the trail you just came up, go off the backside to the right, look for a tree with a trail sign for Maki Lake. At the sign, you can go right to Maki Lake (Trail #135) or left to continue on the loop to Lake Fork (the Maki Lake Trail eventually connects up with the East Fork Lake Fork Trail. The rest of this description is for the East Fork Lake Fork Trail #104. \r\n\nAfter half a mile, the grade eases off and it becomes a nice gentle, well-established downhill trail. You'll pass through a large avalanche debris field. McCall Smokejumpers cut out the debris in 2014 to re-establish the trail. The trail passes through several meadows and stands of timber and eventually runs alongside the East Fork of Lake Fork creek. You'll cross the creek a few times, but you can keep your feet dry by rock hopping. \r\n\nAs you closer you get to the Lake Fork Trailhead, you may see mountain bikers or hunters (if it is fall). The huckleberry picking on this trail has been great the past couple of years; most of the pickers stay within a mile of the Lake Fork Trailhead. At approximately 10.1 miles, you'll come to a trail junction (it's well signed). Continue straight to the Lake Fork Trailhead, 1.7 miles ahead (Trail #339). A left turn puts you on the trail to Anderson Lake (#103).", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7026194/fall-colors-erupt-on-the-lake-fork-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 10.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [7869, 5643], "alt-change": [2050, 2324], "avg-grade": 8.0, "max-grade": 52.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7025316/lake-fork-trail-339", "title": "Lake Fork Trail #339", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.936963,-115.941592", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7025316", "info-text": {"description": "Park at the Lake Fork dispersed campground and hike to the back of the campground. This trail is popular with mountain bikers because of the mostly flat tread. They keep it pretty well cut out too. At about 0.7 miles the trail takes a hard left; look for an arrow on a tree. You can go straight and end up at the same place but the right fork has a steeper section that the mountain bikers like to avoid. There's a small climb as you approach one mile, and then the trail returns to a gentle rolling trail.\r\n\nAt 1.7 miles, you come to a junction, go straight for the East Fork Lake Fork (Snowslide) Trail #104 and turn right for the Anderson Lake Trail #103.  \r\n\nThe huckleberry picking is pretty good along this trail. Because it is close to town and relatively flat, a lot of pickers visit it, but it seems they rarely head more than a mile down the trail.", "features": "River/Creek", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7027047/this-is-the-junction-of-the-east-fork-lake-fork-trail-and-the-anderson-lake-trai", "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 1.5, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [5645, 5393], "alt-change": [262, 76], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 27.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7025694/paddy-flatlake-fork-creek-trail-103", "title": "Paddy Flat/Lake Fork Creek Trail #103", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.922882,-115.932941", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7025694", "info-text": {"description": "The Paddy Flat/Lake Fork Creek Trail (#103) makes a great connection between the Boulder Lake area and the East Fork Lake Fork area. If you start on the north end, it's a good steady climb to the pass below Boulder Mountain, then a nice downhill to Boulder Lake. Early in the summer, your feet will get wet crossing a couple of small creeks. There are lots of huckleberry bushes in this section. \r\n\nOnce you cross the South Fork Lake Fork, the trail starts to climb a few switchbacks for half a mile. After you gain the ridge, you're still climbing but the grade is less steep. The trail is mostly in the shade of the forest but when you get to a large meadow, step off the trail to the east and check out the view of the ridgeline.\r\n\nThis trail doesn't actually go to Anderson Lake, but there is a short trail off to the west that will take you down to the lake, if you'd like to explore this rather scenic destination. \r\n\nThe pass below Boulder Mountain is at 7,777' and provides a great view of Boulder Lake, the Rapid Creek drainage, and Buckhorn Mountain. Once you get past the crowds hanging around the Boulder Lake dam, you'll pretty much have the trail to yourself. The climbs are fairly mellow, except for one short, rocky section. Hikers will be rewarded with great views into the South Fork of the Salmon River watershed from Buckhorn Summit.\r\n\nThe west end of the Buckhorn Trail (#96) starts just past Boulder Lake (Boulder Lake Trail #105). The Buckhorn Trail climbs slowly across a huge meadow and Buckhorn Mountain (8,457') is in the distance. After 0.4 miles, there is trail junction. Go left for the Buckhorn Trail; go right for Kennally Creek Trail (#102). The Buckhorn Trail continues to climb slightly, then there is a short, rocky section up to a ridge line. Then the trail drops a bit down to Summit Lake. A lot of this trail is built on some old logging road, unlike a lot of the other trails that were just pioneered up the side of the mountain in search of mines. You'll defiantly see some of the old road cuts as you hike this trail. It appears the area was logged in the 50s or 60s and the road to trail conversion has fully taken since then. The trail is defiantly a singletrack. \r\n\nThere are some open faces along the way, but most of the time you'll find some nice shade. You also don't have to worry about too many rocks or exposure. Settle in for the long climb and stop along the way to catch your breath and take in the views. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7003511/bench-creek", "title": "Bench Creek", "difficulty": "Very Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.290678,-115.162519", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7003511", "info-text": {"description": "The Bench Creek trail takes you past two rarely visited lakes, but with solitude also comes a trail that's a little less traveled. There will be some meadow sections where the trail becomes faint. Hiking from Trap Creek you'll have a gradual climb to a high point of the trail before descending more steeply off the backside of the mountain. This trail is a great way to make a loop in between Trap Creek and the Elk Mountain Trail.\r\n\nThe descent off of the first high point is very technical and should be descended knowing that help is a long ways off, so watch those ankles. When you hit the Elk Mountain Trail, you'll continue up Elk Creek. The trail from this point is non-motorized, so it can be very primitive at times and will take you all the way over to Iron Creek. Good route finding is a must in this section since you'll definitely lose sight of the trail in the meadows. Make sure you have up-to-date Idaho data downloaded on the Hiking Project mobile app and use it if you have trouble. You'll be rewarded with some amazing views and great lakes as you work your way along this trail.\r\n\nThe lakes do have fishing, so if you pack in your own fishing rod you can land yourself some large trout.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 12.8, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [8636, 6763], "alt-change": [2697, 3148], "avg-grade": 9.0, "max-grade": 44.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7003516/little-casino", "title": "Little Casino", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.195092,-114.896618", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7003516", "info-text": {"description": "This trail can be completed in any number of combinations as an out and back or a bigger loop. You can climb Big Casino and Sunny Gulch and then descend to Little Casino or you can climb Boundary Creek and then descend Sunny Gulch to Little Casino. \r\n\nThe trail is a very moderate grade the entire way, so it makes for a nice long downhill. There has been a lot of work done recently to reduce stream crossings so your feet will stay drier. At the top of the trail you'll go through a number of meadows and this is where you need to be very careful with watching which way the trail goes since people constantly make wrong turns and then lead others astray. \r\n\nIf you end up in some tall grass, you might want to backtrack to make sure you did not miss a turn. The trail skirts a number of meadows, so you get some great views and may spot some wildlife. About halfway down, you'll enter into thicker timber and leave a lot of the meadows. Eventually, the trail will follow the creek the rest of the way down. The trail is very smooth in sections with some quick ups.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 6.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [7583, 6133], "alt-change": [284, 1545], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 16.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7003535/grand-prize", "title": "Grand Prize", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.934613,-114.691236", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7003535", "info-text": {"description": "This trail offers great views of the surrounding mountain range. Youll begin by crossing Pole Creek and start by following an old mining road, take a left at the first fork. Theres no sign so pay close attention. 2 miles later there will be a trail sign on a tree; take a right when you reach it. \n\nAt 3 miles in you'll reach the pass and an expansive meadow at an elevation of 9300 ft. From here, the descent is open. The tread is very narrow in spots so please keep on track to preserve this amazing trail. Lots of big old trees near the pass open up into a wide sagebrush valley. Near the end of the trail, you'll come to a major river crossing. During high water, you can detour to the left here on a trail that will lead you to the Bowery Guard Station and a nice bridge. When the water is low, simply continue on the main trail to the Guard Station. \n\nNear the guard station, there is a hot spring that involves and nice tub that you fill with a hose. This is worth a stop to at least check out if you are into soaking.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7002668/the-downhill-on-the-eastfork-of-the-salmon-river", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 13.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [9066, 6780], "alt-change": [1328, 2302], "avg-grade": 5.0, "max-grade": 15.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7003536/big-smoky-trail", "title": "Big Smoky Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.807931,-114.747866", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7003536", "info-text": {"description": "Big Smoky starts at the Mule Creek Trail on the pass. You'll enter an expansive meadow and pass the headwaters of mighty Salmon River! From this point, the trail is all very narrow singletrack. Users will need to understand that there are no bailout options, come prepared.\r\n\nAfter passing through the meadow, the trail descends steeply on switchbacks and over rough terrain. There will be some occasional muddy areas, watch out for those since they tend to hide in the grass. The trail then mellows out and you'll begin a series of stream crossings. From here, the trail alternates from short ups and downs to smooth singletrack, followed by rocky sections and talus. A number of trails connect with Big Smoky, so it's easy to track your progress. After about 6 miles, the trail will cross to the west side of the river and remain on that side of the river for the remaining hike.\r\n\nSignage is great along the trail and you'll have no problem navigating. Towards the end of the trail, there is signage that mentions a low and high trail. Unless you are doing this trail in late fall, you'll want to take the high trail. The river can be very dangerous otherwise.\r\n\nTowards the end of the trail there are hot springs for those interested in a soak, enjoy!", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7002667/an-awesome-valley-from-the-big-smoky-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 18.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [8298, 5608], "alt-change": [241, 2922], "avg-grade": 3.0, "max-grade": 13.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7014204/yellowbelly-trail-096", "title": "Yellowbelly Trail #096", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.995275,-114.849295", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7014204", "info-text": {"description": "Take Forest Road 365 from Pettit Lake to a small turn off before the road gets rough. From here it is just over a mile to Yellow Belly Lake. Another 0.5 mile along the shore and you'll come to the better parking area at the end of Forest Road 365. Unless you just want the miles and like sage, I would recommend skipping the first 1.75 miles of the trail and just driving the Forest Road 365. WARNING: Some claim that a 4x4 is required to get in there. However, in Aug 2018, we proved that anyone with a little driving skill can safely drive a 2WD Chevy van, a Nissan Altima, and a Saturn Vue all the way in and back out without issue or damage. \r\n\nAnyway, from the second, better parking area the trail wanders through the woods to Mays Creek Trail #192 that merges in from the right. Almost immediately the trail forks with Pettit Lake Cutoff Trail #041 peeling off to the left. Continue on to the wilderness boundary and get signed in. The trail stays fairly level until you get to the creek crossing that has no bridge. Either head 100 feet upstream to a large log to cross or get those boots off and tenderfoot it across. \r\n\nNow comes the steady climb all the way to Farley Lake. Be sure to be on the lookout for short side trails that have bonus waterfalls and tiny unnamed lakes to see. Farley Lake is your halfway up mark. There are tons of camping areas along the trail and around the various lakes. Continue gaining altitude and enjoying the various waterfalls and lakes. Halfway from Farley Lake to Toxaway Lake is the junction of Edith Lake Trail #040 that climbs hard to the right from a clearing with a poorly spelled trail sign. After having a good laugh at the blundered sign stay left to continue on to \"TOXWAY\". Three more small lakes and a final push takes you up into Toxaway Lake! The trail ends where it meets Alice Lake - Redfish Lake Trail #092 just above an excellent camping area complete with sandy beaches below.\r\n\nOnce you arrive at Toxaway Lake, you may want to take a swim out to the island as we did. If you do take the plunge, please be very self-aware and conscience of your hypothermia risks as it is incredibly brisk water and it only gets colder in the middle. We swam as a group and kept close tabs on each other. Even so, it was a while on the island warming up to safely make the return trip.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Commonly Backpacked \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Swimming \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7068020/toxaway-lake-at-sunrise", "ratings": {"rating": 4.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 8.4, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [8410, 6946], "alt-change": [1581, 123], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 19.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7018659/iron-creek-stanley-lake-trail-7640", "title": "Iron Creek - Stanley Lake Trail #7640", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.198699,-115.013839", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7018659", "info-text": {"description": "Starting at the Iron Creek Trailhead, the trail winds through timber before briefly merging with the Alpine Way Trail just after entering the Sawtooth Wilderness at about a mile. After about 3/4 miles, Alpine Way Trail keeps going, but this trail doubles back and starts climbing the north side of the Iron Creek drainage. After about a mile, you'll come to a crossing of Iron Creek. From here, you'll do a few switchbacks and 3/4 miles to gain the ridge and a spectacular view of Alpine Lake. Continue climbing with a few switchbacks and views until it levels off and you pass a small pond to arrive at Sawtooth Lake as well as the junction with Baron - Sawtooth Lake #7478. You should have almost 4.5 miles on your shoes by now and deserve a swim in the clear blue waters.\r\n\nA final push as you climb around the north end of Sawtooth Lake puts you at the summit of this trail in just 5 miles. Get one last look over your shoulder and drop into a rugged alpine valley spotted with tiny lakes, ponds, and marshes. Just under 2.5 miles from the summit, you'll meet up with Trail Creek Trail from the south and Observation Peak Trail from the west. You have options, but to stay on this trailhead north, you only have 7 miles to go.\r\n\nFYI: You are now doing a section of the Idaho Centennial Trail (a collection of trails and routes that run from Idaho's southern border to the northern border).\r\n\nIn less than two miles as you drop into Stanley Lake, you'll see Bench Creek Trail join you from the west. The trail mellows out and is an easy shallow grade the rest of the way out. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7034567/lola-iron-creek-trail", "title": "Lola-Iron Creek Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.289147,-115.172949", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7034567", "info-text": {"description": "This trail is used to make a lot of other connections or can be done as a couple of different loops. I am going to break it up into three parts. \r\n\nPart 1: (Start to Hwy 21) The trail starts at the pass where the Trap Creek trail ends. You'll start with a steep descent into the valley for Bench Creek. After the steep descent, the trail becomes very mellow and will take you down the valley. The trail is supposed to be singletrack, but has seen some poaching lately by ATVs so you may experience a wider tread as you near highway 21. This trail is usually well maintained and trees are cut out every year.\r\n\nPart 2: (Hwy 21 to Bear Valley Rd. ) The section of the trail from Hwy 21 to Bear Valley road is actually best done using Bear Valley Rd to access the top of the trail. Recently, the welcome to motorcyclists who cut out most of the trees from this trail has been cause for debate, so the conditions on the trail will vary. The trail takes you by some great lakes and nice alpine meadows. Hopefully all legal issues are worked out and the trail can return to normal maintenance that is provided by motorcyclists.\r\n\nPart 3: (End to Bear Valley Rd.) This section of the trail is also best done by climbing up Bear Valley Rd and then traversing the ridge to the Lola Creek drainage. The first part of this section can have a lot of down trees, but it is worth it once you get through the burn area. You'll be treated with some great views and a sustained descent into Lola Creek. This trail has some great views of the lake drainage at the top before descending into thick trees. Down in the bottom, keep an eye out for Elk.", "features": "Lake \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7049005/upper-lola-lake", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 18.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [9169, 6547], "alt-change": [2988, 4596], "avg-grade": 8.0, "max-grade": 40.0}},

Both directions are great hikes down. The first downhill from Sunny Gulch going north will take you by the Casino Lakes and then down Big Casino Creek. This downhill is very rugged and there are numerable roots and big rocks to navigate.\r\n\nHeading south from the high point will take you by Martin Lakes. This way is not as steep but still fairly rugged. Near the end of the trail, you'll enter a burn area. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7035124/williams-creek", "title": "Williams Creek", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.096894,-114.749007", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7035124", "info-text": {"description": "Be aware that Williams Creek is open to motorcycles, horses, and mountain bikers. This is the downhill leg of the Fisher Creek Loop. There is still a climb or two to break up the descent.\r\n\nThe last section will provide a great view of the Sawtooth Mountains just before ending at the trailhead and Pit Toilet.\r\n\nAt the start of this trail, you've got about 400' of climbing to get through. The climb is all singletrack, and not difficult at all. The interesting scenery will keep you occupied, although you might find yourself wondering how beautiful and cool this hike would have been in the deep forest before the fire. \r\n\nEventually you'll reach the obvious high point, then you'll round a corner and down you go! It's hard not to grin on this one - the trail surface is great with tree cover and shade - it's one of the best descents around. Enjoy the views as you make your way down!\r\n\nBut be careful - the trail is especially popular with mountain bikers, who generally ride the trail downhill. Stay alert to keep yourself safe and to ensure the safety of all other trail users.\r\n\nTowards the bottom you'll emerge from the trees into more grassy surroundings, and you've got one more short but sharp climb before descending the rest of the way to your car.", "features": "Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 6.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [8010, 6648], "alt-change": [548, 1507], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 18.0}},

The grade of the trail is mellow in the beginning, but there are a number of rocky areas. \r\n\nEventually, Alturas Creek brings you through a number of meadows and avalanche paths until finally, you get into some dense tree cover. Head on into Marshall Lake and check it out before heading down and out to the east. The next thing you know, you'll pass the Meadow Creek Trail.\r\n\nLooking for more trail time? Continue onto Iron Creek where this trail merges with Iron Creek - Stanley Lake #640 Trail. You'll share a path with the Iron Creek - Stanley Lake #640 Trail for about 0.6 miles before continuing north as it cuts back and away. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7056069/hell-roaring-trail-097", "title": "Hell Roaring Trail #097", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.025699,-114.841946", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7056069", "info-text": {"description": "Start your hike right at the Salmon River! Get the worst of it over within the first mile as you gain 350 feet. Yep, that is easy, and the worst of the climb all at once. The next 4 miles to Hell Roaring Lake is a very mild climb as you follow the meandering Hell Roaring Creek. \r\n\nAt 3.4 miles, up you come to the junction with Trail #089 coming in on the left from a parking area at the end of Forest Road #315. The trail leads off to the right and has some interpretative signage about the Urie Homestead, which was a turkey farm and a mining camp established around 1915. The walls of the old house are still standing, but a recent fire damaged it significantly. The trail forks at the ruins. One fork follows the river, and provides views of waterfowl, rapids, and a rich riparian environment. The trail also gets somewhat close to the edge of some cliff bands that hang over the river, so that can get your heart racing if you are on a bike! These cliff outcroppings also provide excellent views of the river, its rapids, and Auger Falls, a 30-foot drop in the river that corkscrews in a different direction than the main flow of the river. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012840/fish-and-game-habitat-trail", "title": "Fish and Game Habitat Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=46.383817,-116.950625", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012840", "info-text": {"description": "This secluded trail is a great escape on the edge of town.  Be sure to note your visit at the trailhead log!\r\n\nThere is a creek that flows into a pond with a nice ramp to an underwater habitat viewing area. In the spring/summer the lily pads bloom bright pink.  You can also see frogs and turtles sunning themselves on the lily pads.  \r\n\nThere is a nice bird observation house and in the winter there are bird feeders around it to keep the birds fat and happy.  Near to the bird observation house is an apple tree that the deer in the area frequent.  Further south in the trail you'll find blackberry bushes for the birds, in addition to walnut and oak trees for the squirrels. You'll also see wild plum, birch, lilac, and Japanese quince that bear a late-summer or early-fall fruit.  \r\n\nOn the east side of the area there are cactus that are native to this part of Idaho.  They bloom butter yellow in June. The main trail is paved and ADA accessible, but there are several small dirt trails to explore some of the hidden areas. There is also a nice picnic bench close to a walnut tree to stop for a bite to eat.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7009750/cacti-dusted-with-snow", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.3, "dist-type": "Lollipop", "alt-range": [1441, 1433], "alt-change": [8, 8], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 2.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7021078/secech-river-trail", "title": "Secech River Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.212326,-115.808803", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7021078", "info-text": {"description": "This trail has a lot of traffic during some times and other times you may see no one. Be sure to check the status of this trail as it can be littered with trees if a recent storm has come through. The up side of all the traffic is that the motorcyclists often bring a saw and clear the trail. This trail also sees a forest service crew about once a year. \r\n\nThis trail provides a nice remote and true backcountry feel without ever getting too far from a main road on either end. With Sesech Hot Spring to sweeten the deal, you must experience this worthwhile trek. This trail travels from the Ponderosa Campground to the Chinook Campground. The trail crosses a couple of small streams as it twists and turns along the bends and curves of the Sesech River. At times, you'll near the banks of the river and at other times you'll travel high above the fast-moving waters. The trail width varies greatly along the entire length and goes from wide path to a narrow trail tucked in along a cliff face. \r\n\nThis trail connects to the Loon Creek Trail and Whangdoodle Trail as well. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7035562/indian-ridge", "title": "Indian Ridge", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.879684,-115.629985", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7035562", "info-text": {"description": "This trail is in the middle of nowhere and far from any help so make sure you are prepared. To access the start of this trail you'll likely have traveled on the Canton Lake Trail and are looking to create a large loop returning back through Yellow Pine. There is also the option to do an out and back from the end of the trail and hike to Indian Peak. A smaller loop option can be done using the Phoebe Meadow Trail and South Fork of the Salmon River Rd. There are lots of possible combinations and variations using this trail.\r\n\nFrom the start of this trail (from either starting point), you'll have some moderate climbing. The grade is mellow and the trail is in good condition. The descent has a couple short and steep ups, but you are on a general downward trend. \r\n\nOnce you hit mile 10, the trail will start dropping a lot steeper, and you'll rapidly head toward the river. At about mile 11.5, you'll enter into a series of switchbacks some of them with loose footing.\r\n\nThe trail ends at the Krassel Guard Station which is on the national historic register; there are also a number of prehistoric sites at the end of the trail so it is worth stopping in after your hike to look around even if the buildings are closed.\r\n\n***Here is a description of the Ranger Station site taken from the National Historic Register***\r\nThe historic part of the property includes the main administrative area with four frame buildings and a Civilian Conservation Core-constructed pack bridge.  All of the buildings are good examples of structures constructed by the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) although only the ranger's residence (Building #1113), the warehouse (Building #1316) and the pack bridge were constructed on-site. The other two structures were constructed by the CCC for similar use at other sites in the area (Poverty Flat and Lake Fork) and were moved to Krassel in 1954. The two CCC-constructed buildings moved from Poverty Flats and Lake Fork to Krassel in 1954 illustrate the Forest Service efforts at re-use of structures and consolidation of certain administrative roles in the 1950s and 1960s.", "features": "Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7035776/great-vistas", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 13.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [7854, 3800], "alt-change": [1859, 5377], "avg-grade": 10.0, "max-grade": 40.0}},

At about mile 8 there is a large avalanche zone that can fill up with trees so beware of this section since it can be a little confusing. Keep on heading up the drainage and you'll come to the trail again. Once past the avalanche zone the trail makes its final steep climb to the top of the drainage and the pass. From here you have commanding views and lots of options depending on where you want to head to.
