{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7036904/krassel-knob-trail", "title": "Krassel Knob Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.970249,-115.732276", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7036904", "info-text": {"description": "Do you like switchbacks? This trail starts near the Krassel Guard station and climbs steeply up to Krassel Knob. The climb up to the knob has so many switchbacks that you'll loose count as you go back and forth again and again. Despite the switchbacks, this climb is very steep, but it has some amazing views.\r\n\nOnce at the top of the Knob you'll have a choice to turn right onto Six Mile Ridge North Segment or left onto the Six Mile Ridge South Segment or just continue straight. The trail will descend and connect into the Buckhorn drainages to create a nice loop. The downhill is a series of long roller coasters, with some short ups and long downhills. There are some loose sections on the trail, but it is fun as it descends into the Buckhorn drainages. \r\n\nThe trail ends at the West Fork of the Buckhorn. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7003506/link-trail", "title": "Link Trail", "difficulty": "Very Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.254741,-115.37259", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7003506", "info-text": {"description": "This trail starts off of Kirkham Ridge and then descends to Warm Springs. In this direction, there's minimal climbing and lots of descending after working hard on the Kirkham Ridge trail to get there. This trail features a lot of open ridge riding and has some immense views.\r\n\nYou can go in the opposite direction, but be prepared for a lot climbing in the first couple of miles. If you are out of gas by the time you hit the first peak then it is best to turn around and try another route. Once you reach the second peak you'll have lots of mellow climbing along the ridge for a long time with one last grunt over the top.\r\n\nYou'll be moving through some fire scars in the landscape. You can see from the aerials some of the recent fires, so bear in mind that these sections may have more downed trees to climb over the earlier in the season you attempt the trail.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 12.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [8105, 5350], "alt-change": [1871, 4019], "avg-grade": 9.0, "max-grade": 49.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7003507/kirkham-ridge", "title": "Kirkham Ridge", "difficulty": "Very Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.307298,-115.262672", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7003507", "info-text": {"description": "This trail is the singletrack portion of the Kirkham Ridge Trail and is a great way to access a number of other loops. The easiest loop to put together is to the take the Ridge Trail to the Link Trail and then return on the Warm Springs trail. Putting together a loop with Gates Creek is also a possibility. Or, using the ridge trail to access the Red Mountain Lakes is another option. \r\n\nGiven that this is a ridge, trail there are lots of ups and downs traveling across this mountains range. Also, you'll be moving across different fire landscapes. You can see some of the recent fires from the aerial imagery, so bear in mind that these sections may have more downed trees to climb over the earlier in the season you attempt the trail.\r\n\nThe trail starts at Bull Trout lake simply because it provides better access to the recommended loops. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7034882/eagles-nest-trail-111", "title": "Eagle's Nest Trail 111", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.644968,-115.845895", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7034882", "info-text": {"description": "The Eagles Nest Trail is divided into three parts. The lower section is the most popular and is usually traveled in combination with the forest service road. The middle section is rougher than the lower section and also requires some steeper climbs. The upper section is remote and very rugged.\r\n\nUpper Section: Mile 0 to 5\r\nThe upper section is best accessed from FS497 or a combination of other trails near Warm Lake. This section is the most demanding and remote of all the sections and does not see a lot of usage. \r\n\nMiddle Section: Mile 5 to 8.5\r\nThe Middle Section of the trail goes from the first road junction on FS400 to the second road junction with FS400. The middle section can be done as an out and back or the trail can be accessed by using the FS400 road. As an out and back you'll have a steep and slighly loose climb to a summit followed by a descent down the backside to FS400. \r\n\nStarting from the top of the middle section using FS400 will result in climbing a moderate grade to the summit in thick tree cover. The climb from the road is rooty and rocky and can be wet as you climb up towards the summit. Once at the summit the trail leaves the thicker tree cover and will become sandier and looser and then will be steep and loose as you descend back to FS400.\r\n\nLower Section: Mile 8.5 to 14\r\nThe lower section begins with the junction of FS400 and takes you down to the parking lot. This is the most popular section and will have the most hikers. From FS400 there is a short climb and then you'll head into a moderate descent across the ridge and with a quick burst up another hill you begin the steep downhill.  As you come upon the sight of a dirt road you'll hit a short, moderately difficult section and a steep ascent. \r\n\nThis was your final burst uphill. Now you'll cruise downhill through lots of overgrowth and fun turns with a couple of exciting drops. You'll drop into a short 0.1 mile section of road, don't miss the trail sign back to the right and you'll make your way into the valley and do a short flat section back to the car. \r\n\nNote: Many people make a loop climbing up 2.5 miles of highway 55 and turning left at rd. #400.", "features": "Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 14.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [7277, 4856], "alt-change": [1506, 3692], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 30.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7035302/middle-fork-payette-river", "title": "Middle Fork Payette River", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.36016,-115.85981", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7035302", "info-text": {"description": "This trail starts at the northern end of Forest Service Rd. #698 and travels north along the Middle Fork of the Payette River. At the beginning of the trail, you'll overlook the historical Boiling Springs Guard Station. This cabin can be rented for your next Middle Fork adventure. \r\n\nThere are a number of side trails along this route that others have used to avoid crossing the river, though it is best to avoid these options and stay on the main trail. The lower portion of the trail crosses the river 17 times. So, it is best to avoid this trail in the spring. \r\n\nThis trail is best from July through October to ensure all of the crossing are low enough. About two miles up the trail, you'll come to a series of hot springs. The best of the hot springs is the Pine Burl Hot Springs that features two nicely sized pools and pipes for adjusting hot and cold water flow. This is accessed by detouring up dash creek about 100ft. The hot spring does make for a nice soak on the way back down this trail to warm up your feet after all of the water crossings.\r\n\nBeyond the hot springs, the trail becomes more rustic and your chance of seeing someone is very slim. The trail stays close to the river and is very scenic as it weaves up the canyon. The water crossings continue, but it is fair to say this is an amazing backcountry experience. As you near the end the trail will start to climb before it levels out again. This trail is only cut free of trees every three years so keep that in mind when attempting this trail.", "features": "Hot Spring \u00b7 River/Creek", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7035600/the-middle-fork", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 16.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [6079, 4040], "alt-change": [3001, 1189], "avg-grade": 5.0, "max-grade": 41.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7035448/west-mountain-trail-131", "title": "West Mountain Trail #131", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.480652,-116.204915", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7035448", "info-text": {"description": "The trail begins in a valley, crossing several creeks, and passing through meadows and forests slowing ascending the West Mountain Ridge. You'll then reach the northern end of Wilson Meadows, which can be boggy in the early part of the year. At the southern edge of Wilson Meadows, the West Mountain Trail is intersected by two other trails. The trail gradually climbs southward towards Jacob's Ladder. \r\n\nAfter passing Jacob's Ladder you'll approach Hangman's Tree, which is signed in a prominent saddle north of Tripod Lookout. Here is a good place to take care of your unruly friends. Within a half mile you'll then pass the Renwyck #138 Trail and then you'll intersects with a short trail that climbs to Tripod Lookout. After Tripod Lookout you'll descend. There is an unblazed section of trail that overlaps an unsigned, well-traveled road for a quarter mile before the trail turns off the road and travels in a southwest direction. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7037410/renwyck-trail-138", "title": "Renwyck Trail #138", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.368849,-116.195672", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7037410", "info-text": {"description": "The trail climbs through dense tree cover on the west side of Renwyck Creek. After it crosses the creek, it starts a series of switchbacks as it ascends through several wet areas to the ridge between the North Fork of the Payette River and Squaw Creek. Once up out of the bottom, views of the drainage and hills to the west are impressive. The trail gets quite steep for the last mile. The trail ends at its junction with the West Mountain Trail #131.\r\n\nAt times, a lot of cows can be grazing in the area so beware of faint trails when in the open meadows. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7037458/cottonwood-creek-trail", "title": "Cottonwood Creek Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.659439,-115.834944", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7037458", "info-text": {"description": "The Cottonwood Creek Trail is a very popular trail and sees usage from hikers, horseback riders, and mountain bikers on busy weekends. Most of the trail is of moderate grade, and this makes it a great out and back. It is also common to use the Cottonwood Creek Rd and Bald Mountain Rd. to create a loop. There is nice camping at the bottom of the trail and also at the top at Thorn Creek Butte so this is a good place to spend the weekend. There are also hot springs up the road along the Middle Fork of the Boise if you need to heal some aching muscles.\r\n\nThe start of this hike is at the bottom of Cottonwood Creek, but as mentioned above it can be done in many different ways. The lower 7 miles of the trail are of moderate grade and are easily climbed. The last 1.3 miles of this trail are steeper (and a little looser) as the creek dies out and you get close to Thorn Creek Butte. \r\n\nA couple of old burns have crossed the trail over the years, so be aware there is not a lot of shade on the lower half of the trail. Near the top you'll enter thicker tree cover and the trail gets a lot more shaded.\r\n\nNote this trail was cut back the first 3 miles by the Forest Service and Idaho Trails Association in the spring of 2019. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7061091/west-warrior-trail", "title": "West Warrior Trail", "difficulty": "Very Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.906078,-115.339649", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7061091", "info-text": {"description": "The West Warrior Trail is an absolutely spectacular trail in one of the wildest settings one can hike in Idaho. If technical hiking on rugged exposed terrain on a ridge is your cup of tea, this trail will blow your mind. \r\n\nTo access the west side of this trail, you'll have to climb up Horse Heaven Trail from either direction to the high point on that trail. Starting from this saddle, climb up to Swanholm Peak. This isn't too bad, although there are a few sections that'll hint at what's to come.\r\n\nFrom Swanholm Peak, you'll hike a low-traffic trail along the ridge to your west. It's smooth at times, and more technical at others. As you proceed along the ridge, you'll pass several lakes to your right, which make for an epic lunch spot or campsite. Eventually, you'll hit an intersection with the Lodgepole Trail. This point marks the start of the descent. \r\n\nThe descent to Black Warrior Creek starts gentle, but quickly develops quite the downward slope. The trail heads straight down a steep ridge with lots of loose scree. Don't think your hike is over once you're down off the mountains though. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7086220/idaho-centennial-trail-section-15", "title": "Idaho Centennial Trail: Section 15", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.399481,-115.193134", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7086220", "info-text": {"description": "The trail begins by following a stretch of dirt road heading to the east. After several miles of rolling hills, the trail turns and heads north, going down Hunter Creek Canyon. A moderate decline following Hunter Creek takes trail users through several nice camping areas, including a large transfer camp, where livestock are moved to and from this mountainous region for seasonal grazing. \r\n\nThe trail then connects with the south fork of Lime Creek and heads up canyon for a very short stretch. It then hops over a small ridge and crosses over into the middle fork of Lime Creek. Trail users then head down canyon for a short leg, until the middle fork and north fork of Lime Creek connect. Adventurers will then head north, going up the north fork of Lime Creek. At this point, a slow, steady climb begins up the canyon. \r\n\nThis entire section is thickly vegetated, with lush layers of underbrush thriving on the flowing waters of Hunter and Lime Creeks. Sections of the trail quickly become overgrown, especially since this area sees very little use. It is important to bring maps and orienteering equipment to help you in case you lose the path. There are also numerous other trails in the area, so it is easy to go up the wrong canyon in many places. The trail then drops precipitously into Virginia Gulch, losing 2,000 feet over 2.5 miles. \r\n\nThe trail throughout is difficult to find at times, and there are numerous trails and roads that cross this route. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7015990/cdt-bannock-pass-to-lemhi-pass-mt-sec-8", "title": "CDT: Bannock Pass to Lemhi Pass (MT Sec. 8)", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.814242,-113.272688", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7015990", "info-text": {"description": "The CDT from Bannock Pass to Lemhi Pass closely follows the crest of the Continental Divide and the Idaho/Montana border. The tread is mixed between the two passes with the southern half following singletrack and the northern half on two-track. Water sources are signed but may be dry if it is late in the season. \r\n\nThe following describes this CDT section from south to north. \r\n\nLeaving Bannock Pass, the CDT briefly (for ~1/4 mi) follows Grizzly Hill Road USFS#012 then cuts up to the divide. This is marked with a lone post and CDT emblem. There is a fence along the state line, wire at first and then crossbuck, from here to Grizzly Hill. The CDT follows singletrack and stays on the Idaho side of the fence all the way to an old microwave complex where the trail meets the two-track. \r\n\nThere are several ring-latch gates along the singletrack CDT, one of them at the above road crossing where the trail now crosses to the Montana side and continues through the woods. There are CDT emblems on some trees and the trail offers a few view into the Clark Valley of Montana as it skirts the east side of Grizzly Hill. \r\n\nThe trail then crosses back to the Idaho side when it leaves the woods for a wide sage expanse at the head of Little Eight Mile Creek. Here you are met with a breathtaking view of Goat Mountain and, to the west, the Lemhi Range. Once across Little Eightmile, the CDT climbs and crosses the border several times and is, in general, great trail. \r\n\nAs the CDT nears the east flank of Goat Mountain, it becomes two-track. The road pretty much follows exactly along the crest of the divide. There are wide open alpine meadows separated by timbered sections. The CDT can be flat and easy or very steep up/down. The road loses a lot of elevation as it nears Lemhi Pass.", "features": "Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 27.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [9478, 7365], "alt-change": [4330, 4632], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 28.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7015992/cdt-lemhi-pass-to-goldstone-pass-mt-sec-9", "title": "CDT: Lemhi Pass to Goldstone Pass (MT Sec. 9)", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.974564,-113.444949", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7015992", "info-text": {"description": "The southern 14 miles of this section of the CDT, from Lemhi Pass to the high point above the head of Kenney Creek follows pleasant singletrack through pine forests. Blazes on trees and the occasional CDT emblem guide the way. To the west, FS Road 185 and 184 closely parallel this section and here is also access to the east at Eunice Creek. Early on, there are a couple of viewpoints near Lemhi Pass. Overall progress is good except for infrequent rocky sections.\r\n\nAround mile 14, the CDT turns uphill steeply and climbs above 9,000' to near the timberline. The trail becomes much more remote and wild with steep rocky sections. The CDT is marked with cairns as it travels along the open ridgelines and past phenomenal views over both states. If you look closely, you can see evidence of historic mining activity in the basins below the divide. \r\n\nJust north of Goldstone Mountain, the trail tops 9,700' with a very steep and rocky section The trail continues steeply down from this high point and meets a two-track at Goldstone Pass after a short singletrack section. From Goldstone Pass to the east is good two-track on the Goldstone Road into Montana, offering loop opportunities with the CDT. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7033993/hay-knapp-creek-eastern-segment", "title": "Hay-Knapp Creek (Eastern Segment)", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.316734,-114.736556", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7033993", "info-text": {"description": "The trail begins as an ATV trail at the end of an old mining road. There have been some switchbacks added to help mellow out the climb, but you'll surely be pushing your heart rate in the first mile and a half. \r\n\nOnce on the ridgeline, you'll follow the spine until you come to a trail junction. The ATV route will turn left and you'll continue on the ridge onto 6.4 miles of singletrack. Just after leaving the ATV trail, start looking down to your left and you'll see an alpine lake tucked in the mountains along with some great meadows. \r\n\nAt the junction with the East Basin Lake Trail, you can follow the trail down and into the lakes basin if you are looking for a detour. Leaving the lakes behind, you'll continue on the ridge and then start a steep descent into Hay Creek. \r\n\nAfter the steep descent, the trail will again become an ATV track. You'll continue down Hay Creek on the ATV trail for about 3.5 miles. Then you'll bear right at the junction to continue on the trail and it will again become singletrack. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7085981/mt-borah", "title": "Mt. Borah", "difficulty": "Very Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.13254,-113.834531", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7085981", "info-text": {"description": "The grand pinnacle in the Lost River Range and Idaho as a whole is Mount Borah, also referred to as Borah Peak. During the 4 miles up this monolith, you'll almost gain a full mile in elevation (5,200 feet). The first mile is about 1,000 feet of elevation gain and a good warm-up for what lays ahead. \r\n\nMile 2 is more than double the elevation, at over 2,000 feet of climbing. At about mile 2.2, you are out of the treeline and exposed the rest of the way. Mile 3 starts out fairly flat with a mild incline and then you hit the infamous Chicken-Out Ridge (COR). COR is not to be taken lightly. If people \"chicken out,\" it is usually right at the start or at the end of this 0.25-mile section of scrambling. \r\n\nIf you are afraid of heights, do not attempt COR. Do not attempt to bypass COR by dropping down below it. Custer County Sheriffs department and many trail guides warn that the lower west section is where people get hurt and a few decades ago even died. As a rule of thumb, when in doubt, stay on the ridge/spine. \r\n\nAt the end of COR is a Class 4 scramble.There will sometimes be a climbing rope there, but it is still doable without a rope. You drop down onto a knife ridge that in early summer will be covered in snow. This can be very dangerous. There is a flat-ish section after COR, and then the final 0.5 miles is straight up to the summit. Stay on the defined trail. \r\n\nAfter COR, you do not spend very much time on the ridge. The summit is amazing and well worth the price of entry. Record your name in the logbook, snag a picture with the summit flag in the white tube, and prepare to thrash your quads as you blaze back to the trailhead. \r\n\nNOTE: The GPX track I recorded is very accurate, with any variations cleaned up. This is the traditional route. The official Forest Service trail ends at the start of COR, so after that it's the \"wild west.\"", "features": "Geological Significance \u00b7 Historical Significance \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7084791/view-from-the-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 5}, "stats": {"dist": 3.9, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [12489, 7412], "alt-change": [5087, 17], "avg-grade": 25.0, "max-grade": 77.0}},

This trail is a non-motorized trail and does see yearly maintenance once the snow clears. \r\n\nThe trail is mostly mellow and is in thick tree cover for most of its length. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7036099/lower-salmon-river-trail", "title": "Lower Salmon River Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.402058,-116.11777", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7036099", "info-text": {"description": "This trail is an old one and is also referred to as the Scott Ranch route, which was used by miners and freighters during the Florence gold rush of the 1860s. The Lower Salmon River Trail is all that remains of the Northside River Trail that was used until the CCC constructed the Salmon River Road in the 1930s. \r\n\nThis route is also a section of the historic Milner Trail which provided access during the gold mining days. The trail begins at the second bridge across the Salmon river known as the Manning Crevice Bridge, there is very limited parking here at the bridge, so keep this in mind and make sure not to block the road. \r\n\nThe trail follows the river and has some short ups and downs and there are some challenging rocky spots along the way. The trail also leads to Cave Hot Springs so it is sometimes frequented by soakers. There are some exposed sections along the trail and there is basically no shade, so this would be a brutal hike during the summer months in the middle of the day. \r\n\nHike this trail early or late in the summer or early in the morning, otherwise you might need to dip in the river!", "features": "River/Creek", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 5.4, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2167, 1889], "alt-change": [558, 533], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 21.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7036383/yakima-mine-trail", "title": "Yakima Mine Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.433088,-116.008544", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7036383", "info-text": {"description": "The Yakima Mine Trail is a lightly maintained route that provides a nice remote and primitive experience. Start from the Castle Creek Campground, cross the highway to the gated dirt road. The road soon forks, one fork going up the creek, the other crossing the creek. Expect to see many down trees.\r\n\nThe trail drops down into the canyon of Twentymile Creek which it crosses with a ford before climbing  up the other side of the canyon. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7098630/driveway-trail-431", "title": "Driveway Trail #431", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.683813,-116.013161", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7098630", "info-text": {"description": "Trailhead is located off Hungry Ridge Road #309A and runs all the way to Sourdough Peak.\r\n\nClimb just one mile to Camp Creek Road #9325. The trail merges with the road for 0.5 miles before skipping a well-designed switchback in favor of a hard climb. Climb 2.25 miles, crossing Camp Creek Road #9325 on a steady climb to the ridge and the junction of Marble Point Trail #328. This is also a northwest point of the Gospel-Hump Wilderness boundary. The trail and Wilderness Boundary are one and the same for the next four miles down into Gospel Creek. \r\n\nAlso of note, Gospel Creek Trail #305 drops off into the Wilderness at about 2.5 miles east of Marble Point Trail #328 junction. \r\n\nFrom the Gospel Creek crossing, you'll immediately cross Johns Creek as well. At this point, the trail leaves the Wilderness Boundary and starts a steep two-mile climb up out of Johns Creek drainage to the junction of Snoose Creek Trail #407. \r\n\nNext, go four miles heading for a saddle and out around a ridge to the next saddle before climbing to the Peak of Sourdough Peak.", "features": "Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 13.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [6776, 4012], "alt-change": [5088, 3385], "avg-grade": 12.0, "max-grade": 82.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7015018/over-the-top", "title": "Over The Top", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.822339,-112.466217", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7015018", "info-text": {"description": "Most people take this trail this from south to north. It begins with a few easy switchbacks out of the Cusick Creek drainage, then winds through aspens before side-hilling out onto a ridge overlooking town. Look back toward the draw you just ascended out of, and you might see a moose.\r\n\nFrom the overlook the trail turns back west across the ridge, winds through the trees in the bottom of the draw again, then kicks out to a few more switchbacks before cresting the ridge at the top. There's normally a snow drift at the top in the spring, but it's easy to cross.\r\n\nThe downhill begins along a sidehill through a few rocky sections, then turns the corner on the ridge where the fun begins. Two tight switchbacks at the top, a handful of rock slides, then on to a series of 9 more switchbacks in short succession. \r\n\nAfter the switchbacks the trail heads back toward town, alternating through wooded draws and open hillsides. There's one last set of switchbacks near the end. It's a bit steep, and some people have taken to shortcutting straight down the ridge. Please stay on the trail. \r\n\nThere is also a fork here, and the left branch takes you to upper Sullivan's. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7029284/waterline-trail", "title": "Waterline Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.818208,-112.425397", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7029284", "info-text": {"description": "The trailhead is at the top of Juniper Hill Dr. and Lance Drive. Between two houses is an access road owned by the city that leads to a water tank. About 100 yard up the road on the right, the singletrack starts. From there, the trail follows a cut in the side of the mountain placed there decades ago to run a water pipe to the then new residential area of Johnny Creek. The pipe was decommissioned after a new well and tank were installed.  \r\n\nThere are some spots along the trail where you can see parts of the original pipe, now rusted and broken.  The trail follows a level contour for the most part until reaching the meadows area about two miles in. There is a prolonged shallow climb (about .5 miles) before the final descent into the parking lot at Cusick Creek above the women's prison. The parking lot on the west end of this trail can be accessed from S. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7003550/becks-ditch", "title": "Beck's Ditch", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.313421,-116.698198", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7003550", "info-text": {"description": "This is a classic desert trail in a deep canyon. The trail wanders through Reynolds Canyon's high rhyolite walls along an old ditch built in the early 1900s. The ditch was supposed to bring water to Givens Hot Springs, but filled with sand within the first year, making it unusable. The trail makes use of the ditch and can have some serious drop-offs in many sections. The trail is very technical in sections so one needs to stay on their toes.\r\n\nSince this is horse country, there are a number of faint side trails. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7034912/sheep-creek-126", "title": "Sheep Creek #126", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.494681,-113.82385", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7034912", "info-text": {"description": "Sheep Creek Trail throws it all at you from amazing singletrack to exposed sidehill trail, expect more than the length indicates.\r\n\nSheep Creek Trail leaves the CDT - Bradley Gulch just south of the cabin and descends to the canyon bottom for a stream crossing.  Once across, the trail parallels Sheep Creek for over 1/4 mile and can be overgrown with vegetation.\r\n\nIt then steeply climbs and contours away from the creek, gaining over 800' in the next 1.5 mile.  Glimpses of the Beaverhead Mountains can be had when the trail sidehills across a a steep exposed face with Sheep Creek far below.\r\n\nAfter crossing through a saddle, the trail quickly drops 500' vertical through old burned trees and a few switchbacks. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7031465/targhee-creek-trail", "title": "Targhee Creek Trail", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.670636,-111.312978", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7031465", "info-text": {"description": "Traveling from the Idaho side and just passing Henry's Lake in the world famous Island Park, you'll not believe this trail exists in this particular area until you have had the utter pleasure of taking it for a hike. This is a perfect singletrack trail in numerous ways as you meander up the canyon through the pine trees and across small bridges.\r\n\nThe total distance of this trail, one-way, is just over 6 miles. The first 3.14 miles are flat with minimal elevation gain and then the bridge-less creek crossing marks the start of the climbing. Having warmed up, it's time to cool down as you forge the creek that is a river in June and turns to a trickle by the end of the summer. Over the next 3 miles, you'll see incredible sights as you climb higher and higher. Early in the summer, you'll cross Targhee Creek multiple times and your shoes will get wet. You hike parallel to the creek until the 5.87-mile mark where you cut back to the west and make your final climb until you intersect with the Continental Divide Trail that is marked with a sign. This is the turnaround point or if you have not had enough, a crossroads onto endless trails.\r\n\nIf you want to see Clark Lake it is only another quarter mile to the northeast on the Continental Divide Trail. You'll see a smaller unnamed lake prior to it on your right. Clark is on the left and the epitome of what a high mountain Idaho lake is like. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7034958/big-timber-creek-trail-68131", "title": "Big Timber Creek Trail #6813.1", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.548699,-113.427127", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7034958", "info-text": {"description": "Big Timber Creek Trail can be hikeed as an out-and-back or as a part of several loops, the most common being the Yellow Peak Loop with Rocky Creek Trail. You may want to consider camping if you plan on hiking the entire trail or adding loops. It has some great, smooth singletrack,  some more rugged sections and some unavoidable steeper climbs.\r\n\nAccess to Big Timber Creek is via the Timber Creek Road #105. This is a rough road so many start their hike closer to the USFS kiosk board near Swan Basin. It is 4.5 miles from the kiosk to the start of the trail (please take this extra milage into consideration when planning your hike).\r\n\nThe official beginning of the trail is at a gate across Big Timber Road just uphill from a shallow stream crossing. It then climbs and follows this road, past another wire gate, about 1/4 mile where a good singletrack bears left away from the road.  \r\n\nThis short trail contours down and rejoins the ATV road before descending steeply to parallel Big Timber Creek. The trail is open to ATVs to the next gate.\r\n\nOnce past the ATV gate, the trail is easy to follow and well defined. The trails beyond this gate are still open to MX bikes so don't be surprised to hear some \"brap.\"  Soon after the gate is a stream crossing. This is Rocky Creek and the Rocky Creek Trail #6184 takes off to the right just after this crossing.  \r\n\nThe trail then follows Big Timber Creek along the valley, climbing gently for about another 4 miles before entering the timber and gaining elevation more quickly. This is a short, wet section of trail near the end of the sage valley in an aspen grove and a little ways above the junction with Cabin Creek Trail.\r\n\nAfter entering the timber, the trail gets much more rugged and climbs close to 2000' to the pass between Big Timber and the Park Fork. Much of this section is open sage meadows mixed with steeper more rugged trail.\r\n\nNear the head of Big Timber Creek, the trail crosses several springs and has been badly washed out. Above the washout, the trail crosses a boggy area then turns and climbs up on a steep bench, passing giant white pine skeletons along the way to the pass.\r\n\nNorth of the pass, at 9700', the trail drops 300' vertical across a rocky scree field. There are some beautifully constructed, terraced switchbacks criss-crossed by dirt-bike shortcuts. This makes for a somewhat exposed descent.\r\n\nBeyond the scree field, the trail rolls and climbs along the edge of the head of the Park Fork of Pahsimeroi's Big Creek to the junction with Rocky Creek Trail #6184 where it ends 11.8 miles in.", "features": "Commonly Backpacked \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 11.8, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [9686, 7246], "alt-change": [2857, 844], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 30.0}},

Bring your water shoes and plenty of drinking water. Like all tight canyons in this area, it is susceptible to flash floods so keep an eye on the weather. If there is a flash flood you'll have lots of areas to wait it out but hike at your own risk, not your family's. Unlike Jump Creek Falls, this canyon is for the most part, trash free and clean with the exception of a few boat pieces here and there. (Years ago some hillbillies tried to ride a motor boat down on a flash flood) \r\n\nGetting there: Although I have personally driven a Toyota Yaris to the trailhead and back without damaging it, you may want something with a few more inches of clearance. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7043175/yellowstone-grand-teton-rail-trail-driggs-to-victor", "title": "Yellowstone / Grand Teton Rail Trail - Driggs to Victor", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.708967,-111.110938", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7043175", "info-text": {"description": "The Yellowstone / Grand Teton Rail Trail is officially 104 miles from end to end and is part of our Idaho State Park and Recreational Trailway system. In reality, it is composed of 3 remaining hike-able sections with miles of highway, forest service roads and farm roads connecting the three. As of Nov 2017, these 3 sections will provide you with 78.4 miles of \"Rail Trail\". \r\n\nYou can expect beautiful wooded areas on the northern end and waves farmland and a few trestles on the Southern end of the Rail Trail. You can also expect to enjoy an ever-changing view of the Teton Mountain Range. \r\n\nThe Oregon Pacific Rail lines were established to provide tourist access to the Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks in 1908 and 1913. \r\n\nThe hiking surface is dirt and gravel but obviously, maintain easy RR grades throughout. \r\n\nTHIS SECTION: Flat and straight. Great views of the traffic on Highway 33.\r\n\nFROM TETONIA: (9.8 mi)\r\nTurn left onto Egbert Ave 0.3 mi\r\nTurn right onto N 3000 W 2.0 mi\r\nTurn left onto W 4000 N 2.5 mi\r\nTurn right onto ID-33 E 5.0 mi", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.3, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 7.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [6198, 6081], "alt-change": [178, 67], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 2.0}},

The trail crosses the Snake River via a highway bridge. On either end of the bridge, there are places to easily access the Snake River, which can provide a cool swim during the heat of the day. \r\n\nThe trail continues along the highway after the Snake River, and enters into large fields of various crops. Adventurers will then enter Hammett, a small town of about 500 people. This is the first sign of real civilization in nearly 90 miles along the ICT. \r\n\nHammett has a couple stores, a post office, and a cafe, in case you want to resupply or relax and enjoy a meal. For thru-hikers, this is an important resupply town, since it has one of the only post offices that is along the actual trail. \r\n\nAfter Hammett, the trail continues along paved roads, crossing Interstate 84, and ascending a plateau above the Snake River. Just when you get in a downhill rhythm if flattens out and then climbs again. Wash, rinse, repeat! \r\n\nEven on a windy day, this forested area that sits on the Jefferson and Madison County line border is usually calm and beautiful. Quaky's and pine trees, interspersed with bushes, guide your route and help to protect you from the elements. During the late summer, the trail becomes really dusty so you'll be kicking dirt. During the winter, this is used as a snowshoe trail.\r\n\nThis is National Forest land and is leased out to ranchers. Cows are up in the area during the summer months, and you may have to do dodge \"land mines\". There have been reports of hikers encountering cows and even a bull. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7034695/warm-springs-trail", "title": "Warm Springs Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.641233,-114.415813", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7034695", "info-text": {"description": "The trail is a great downhill hike (taking the lift makes this a great option if you want a great hike without 3,200' of climbing!). The trail is mostly smooth, with a few rocky sections but nothing severe.\r\n\nHowever, if you want a long day (and and early morning to boot), as a climb, this trail begins at the warm springs base area out Warm Springs Road. The first bit of the trail is a bit steep, but don't worry - it becomes more gradual once you get into the trees. The trail switchbacks and traverses all the way to the top of Bald Mountain. This climb is not super technical and ascends at a reasonable grade, but it is long. \r\n\nBeautiful sections of burned trees will open you to many amazing vistas. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7042574/lightning-creek-road-fs-611", "title": "Lightning Creek Road (FS 611)", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.192677,-115.931756", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7042574", "info-text": {"description": "This is a well-maintained dirt/gravel Forest Service road that is passable by most any vehicle up to this point. Locals may choose to hike from Middlefork Road (adding several miles and about 400 feet of climb) if they have an alternative parking spot to the one mapped.\r\n\nThe hike itself is not particularly special; just a steady climb up a dirt road through piney woods. The main use of this route is to access the Rocket Trail for a loop or if you want to add even more climbing to get to Lightning Ridge. There are a number of wood/rubber water bars installed across the road. The road surface is mostly very sandy, so mud is not a major problem.\r\n\nTo get to the parking area, simply drive about 7.0 miles north of Crouch on Middlefork Road and look for the right-turn onto Lightning Creek Road. Drive past the cabins and continue into the National Forest until the first green gate on the right. This is the first good parking spot to start your hike, but others are available further up the road.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7070616/overlooking-lightning-creek", "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 5.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [4584, 3199], "alt-change": [1417, 32], "avg-grade": 5.0, "max-grade": 24.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7042575/rocket-trail", "title": "Rocket Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.190185,-115.909864", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7042575", "info-text": {"description": "This trail provides an alternate route parallel to Lightning Creek Road (FS 611). Although the sign at the bottom end specifies non-motorized use only, it has become an ATV-width trail for its entire length. The best way to hike this trail is to access the upper end using Lightning Creek Road as part of a longer loop.\r\n\nThere's no signage at the upper end, so watch carefully for tracks leaving the road to the left (downhill).  Follow this path through the trees, you'll soon come to the trail's only steep section, then pass the \"Rocket\" on your left and wind your way back down to the gate at the bottom. There are a number of ups and downs and switchbacks to keep things interesting.\r\n\nTo get there, drive about 7.0 miles north of Crouch on Middlefork Road and turn right on Lightning Creek Road. One could start the hike at the bottom to add several miles and about 400 feet of climbing, but there aren't any good parking areas there. So, it's suggested to drive until you see the first green gate (bottom of the Rocket Trail) on the left and park there. Other parking spots are available further up the road as well.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 1.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3967, 3593], "alt-change": [0, 374], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 14.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7050405/wow-trail", "title": "WOW Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.046216,-115.953288", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7050405", "info-text": {"description": "The WOW Trail is a brand-new singletrack out-and-back that's perfect for families, but also fun for hikers of all abilities.\r\n\nTo reach the trailhead, head south on Alder Creek Rd. from Banks-to-Lowman Hwy, crossing the South Fork of the Payette River and continuing up the wide gravel road for about two miles. Look for a brown post marking the trail on the right side, then park about fifty yards ahead in the large pullout on the left.\r\n\nThe trail starts at the brown trail marker signpost, and climbs up to a chain-link u-gate; this is the steepest part of the trail. After you're through the gate, enjoy the easy singletrack meandering through the pines for about 1.5 miles.\r\n\nThe trail is built on a VERY old roadbed that's been abandoned for decades, so the grade is easy and there are no technical sections. However, there are enough trees and shrubs for the trail to wander around that it's pretty fun to hike.\r\n\nThe name WOW stands for Wolverines on Wheels, Garden Valley's youth MTB club and racing team. This trail was built by a joint effort of the Boise County Job Creation and Retention Council, Southwest Idaho Mountain Bike Association, Bureau of Land Management, Boise County Community Justice, and Wolverines on Wheels. It represents the beginning of an effort to provide easily accessible, safe, non-motorized trails for the club, local residents, and visitors to enjoy in Garden Valley. Look for more in the near future!!", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 1.5, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3630, 3373], "alt-change": [287, 31], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 11.0}},

There are many ways to do this trail - either by setting up a car shuttle and hiking it in its entirety, or parking at one of the many pull-offs and enjoying specific segments as an out and back.  \r\n\nThe trail is generally wide with a fine gravel surface and winds through wide meadows of scrub, grasses and scattered wildflowers. Aspen groves and evergreen stands alternate as the trail crosses the river repeatedly. Enjoy views Galena Peak and the impressively colored Boulder Mountains. \r\n\nThe trail crosses numerous side access roads - these intersections are marked by gates for safety. For the most part, the Harriman Trail stays on the south side of Highway 75, but does cross the highway near the Wood River Campground, so use caution in this area. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7034996/spring-creek-trail", "title": "Spring Creek Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.884366,-114.649303", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7034996", "info-text": {"description": "This trail offers a longer option in this area for the more adventurous hikers. From its beginning at Rip and Tear, this trail follows an old FS road grade for just under a half mile, where the Mine Shaft Connector trail intersects with it. After that, the trail turns to singletrack for all but a couple of short sections of its length. \r\n\nWhile the overall elevation drop favors hiking N to S, there is a significant up and down to the trail. The trail runs over five ridges and the creek drainages between them, giving constant changes to the elevation profile. You'll find yourself crossing a couple of FS roads and intersecting with a couple other trails along the way. \r\n\nHikeed all the way to the end, this trail brings hikers back to highway 75, and a 2+ mile hike up the asphalt back to the lodge. Crossing the highway and hiking the Harriman Trail back up to the lodge is another option. \r\n\nSince this trail is popular with mountain bikers there are features on the trail specific to those users, including high banked switchbacks and jumps. These help remind you that this is a multi-use trail and that regardless of right-of-way rules, you should be aware of other users on the trail.", "features": "Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7035419/a-nice-section-of-smooth-trail-headed-into-the-clearing", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 6.4, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [7836, 7121], "alt-change": [641, 1234], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 34.0}},

The scenery on this trail is excellent. Titus Lake is a nice spot to rest to have lunch, and much of the singletrack is quite fun.\r\n\nPark by Galena Lodge, the trail starts on the west side of Hwy 75 on a doubletrack but quickly turns to singletrack. The trail starts out climbing but up some very gentle grades for the first couple of miles. Around 2.5 miles the trail steepens slightly and you'll start to head up some switchbacks. Depending on the time of year the trail can be dusty and loose.  Around 3.5 miles up the trail gets steeper for a few tenths of a mile as it crawls up several more tight switchbacks. Soon after, however, you'll reach Titus Lake, a great place to stop for a rest or lunch. Many people chose to turn around here. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7036659/mineral-point-trail-82", "title": "Mineral Point Trail #82", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=48.177413,-116.406282", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7036659", "info-text": {"description": "This trail is a Kaniksu National Forest Trail, named Mineral Point Trail #82, and is part of a system of trails in the Mineral Point area.  It offers amazing views of the mid-section and northern end of Lake Pend Orielle as well as the large mountain areas called The Monarch Mountains and the The Scotchman Peaks.  It is a well maintained trail with predominately hard-pack dirt with occasional rocky sections.\r\n\nThere are two trailheads. The lower trailhead is located at the Green Bay Camp Area and the upper trailhead is located at the end of Forest Road 532. \r\n\nThis trail features many views of the lake. The main view point is called Mineral Point and is well marked with a stone-cemented plaque monument.  If you are starting from the lower trailhead this is a great place to stop for a little rest before continuing your climb.  \r\nThe trail predominately winds inward from the high, rocky, cliff shores, dipping into the deep parts of the forest from time to time and then popping you out a half-dozen times to beautiful view points.\r\n\nAll in all, this is a very fun trail and a fun area to go get lost in for a 1/2 day adventure.\r\nAfter you are done hiking, head into the town of Sandpoint for some awesome local cuisine, beer and coffee.", "features": "Lake \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7036837/the-views-of-the-green-monarchs-are-great", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 4}, "stats": {"dist": 4.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2544, 2142], "alt-change": [557, 291], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 15.0}},

Maps might be out of date with new roads being built all the time. The road ends at the old lookout tour location, is very, very steep and rocky, and has huge kelly ditches -- you'll need high clearance or an ATV, but there's plenty of parking at the top and also a convenient squat toilet. \r\n\nThe trailhead is clearly seen from the parking area; just start hiking up. It's a great trail with tons of spots for some backpacking opportunities and tons of views! Once at the saddle, you can either enjoy the view of Chimney Rock, or go right or left to summit either peak. Be sure to look to the south for views of Hunt Lake with Gunsight Peak, Lake Pend Oreille in the distance, and also Mount Spokane on clear days. Be sure to look west for views of Priest Lake and Luby Bay and north for the endless view of the Selkirks heading into Canada. It is located in the Danskin Mountains. The route up the mountain takes a cross-country trek across what were once 4wd roads, old motorcycle paths, and well-worn use trails. It starts off 9 miles up Blacks Creek Road from I-84. This is a good early season trip when there is still snow high up in the mountains. In the fall, the area fills with hunters and their activities, so it might be best to avoid this area. There is no water and very little shade on this route.\r\n\nFrom Blacks Creek Road, head northwest along the flank of Three Point Mountain to gain the northern ridge and follow the ridge north to reach the summit of Kepros Mountain. It has a number of rollers and banked turns, which have been burned in by motorcycles. The area recently burned and is currently closed to motorized users, so it is nice and quiet out there.\r\n\nThe trail can be loose in the fall and there are some deep water crossings in the spring. This trail begins at Black Lake and climbs abruptly to the saddle looking down into Emerald Lake. You'll pass a junction to the Six Lakes Basin so make sure to stay right at the junction. There is a small lake before the pass that can dry out by the end of the season, though early in the season, there is usually a great wildflower display. \r\n\nOnce over the saddle, you'll descend down towards Emerald Lake. The trail is very loose coming off the saddle and there is some exposure that you need to careful of. As you dip into the trees, the trail is easy going again, and you'll soon be at Emerald Lake. Emerald Lake has some great meadows and campsites plus lots of great solitude.\r\n\nThe trail beyond Emerald Lake has not been maintained for a number of years and conditions are bound to change from year to year. Beyond Emerald Lake, you'll work your way through a forest for a while as you climb back into the alpine. You'll definitely be going over downed trees in this section until you enter the alpine. Once in the alpine, you'll need to watch for cairns since the trail in the meadow sections can be very faint. Be sure to check your maps frequently to not get misplaced. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7036385/upper-cannon-lake", "title": "Upper Cannon Lake", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.324267,-116.509067", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7036385", "info-text": {"description": "An incredible blue, snow-fed lake awaits your short but steep hiking efforts. This trail has never been officially added to the government trail maps and thus has no maintenance plan. It is, however, somewhat well established with over 150 cairn markers that start on the summit of Lower Cannon Lake Trail #126 just above Lower Cannon Lake. \r\n\nThis trail is quite easy as it runs from cairn to cairn up the ridge. That easy hiking gives way as you start to assault the face of the canyon and climb steeper and steeper. If at anytime you feel like you lost the trail, just stop and scan for a cairn, the trail reappears like magic. (sometimes you wonder how you didn't see it) About 2/3 the way there, the trail plays a bittersweet trick on you, leading you to think you are coming over the top and almost there! It is only a sweet meadow area with a sweet waterfall coming down a sweet cliff! Stay with the cliff as you pass the waterfall and scramble up a steep, somewhat loose trail section to get up out of the meadow area. You are almost there! \r\n\nContinue following the cairns up a steep valley to a great fall camping area and from there down onto the rocky lake shore. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7003538/rooks-creek", "title": "Rooks Creek", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.648865,-114.515454", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7003538", "info-text": {"description": "In 2007, the Castle Rock Fire exploded up Rooks Creek, torching much of the drainage. The canyon bottom, however, was spared from intense burning. Then in 2014 the trail was reconstructed in many parts of the drainage, turning a trail that was overgrown before the fire in 2007 into a pleasant hike. The trail remains a steady climb to the ridge - that was not fixed by the heavy trail work in 2014. \r\n\nThis trail is not as smooth as the trail systems close to town and will certainly have some technical rock features along the way. There are a few landslides that cut across the path of the trail due to the 2007 fire. The most notable and largest is around the halfway point.\r\n\nRooks Creek is also a great way to access the Osberg Ridge Trail or to create some loops towards Adams Gulch.\r\n\nThere was a lot of mining activity on the slopes of Boyle Mountain and a few structures remain in the bottom of Rooks Creek about a mile up the trail.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 6.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [8633, 6404], "alt-change": [2230, 2], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 26.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7003541/adams-gulch", "title": "Adams Gulch", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.724179,-114.492484", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7003541", "info-text": {"description": "This trail climbs above the more popular trails close to town and takes you high into the mountains overlooking Sun Valley. The lower part can be crowded on busy summer days, but once past Griffin Butte Connector, the crowds thin out and the trail begins to take on a more rustic feel.\r\n\nThe climb is slow and steady and will cross some technical talus fields. Close to the creek you'll need to keep an eye out for stinging nettle since it tends to lurk along the stream banks. If you don't know what stinging nettle looks like then look it up. The plant is not poisonous, it just hurts for a little while and can cause small bumps. \r\n\nAs the creek gets smaller, the trail gets steeper. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7014198/alice-lake-redfish-lake-trail-092", "title": "Alice Lake - Redfish Lake Trail #092", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.940073,-114.95252", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7014198", "info-text": {"description": "Starting just above Alice Lake and very near the end of Pettit Creek Trail #095 just before Twin Lakes, start your climb to the summit. Make sure to always look back at each summit to see it all. The trail drops down into Toxaway Lake but stays up off the shore. As you head around the north side of Toxaway Lake you'll need to make a left to stay on the trail or else you'll find yourself on Yellowbelly Trail #096 (if you miss the turn by accident or on purpose, you can take Edith Lake Trail #040 back up to rejoin the trail). \r\n\nThere are great camping spots directly below the junction of Yellowbelly Trail #096 complete with a sandy beach in late summer. From Toxaway Lake, work your way up to a saddle and the junction of South Fork Payette River Trail #452. Stay right and keep climbing up over the next ridge. The trail then drops down into a bowl with views of Edith Lake and Farley Lake below with Yellow Belly Lake out to the East. At the junction of Edith Lake Trail #040, stay left and hop on over the next saddle for great views of Imogen Lake. When you get you Imogene Lake, consider taking a detour on Imogene Lake Trail for some alternate views and access to the intermittent island in late summer. \r\n\nThe next 5 miles are easier going as you drop down into Hell Roaring Lake. At Hell Roaring Lake you'll find sandy beaches in late summer and wooded camping areas. At the end of the lake is the junction of Hell Roaring Trail #097, stay left and start climbing. Halfway up the worst climb of the entire trail, you'll come to the junction of Huckleberry Creek Trail #398, stay left and keep on slogging upward. \r\n\nAfter cresting the ridge, pound those knees down the backside and across Decker Creek before the trail decides to behave properly again. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7034872/skeleton-creek", "title": "Skeleton Creek", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.590271,-115.018429", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7034872", "info-text": {"description": "At 11.7 miles one-way, this can be hikeed as an out-and-back, but maybe not in one day. \r\nKeep in mind the pass is usually snow bound until July.\r\n\nEast Fork of Skeleton Creek is a trail that can be climbed to create a larger loop, or used as an out-and-back. From the bottom of the trail, the first part is fairly mellow climbing with some short steep sections. The later in the season you go, the less likely the trail is to have fallen trees.\r\n\nThe first 6 miles are a pretty mellow ascent, with just a few short steeper sections. After mile 6, the trail gets much steeper. This is to be expected in the Smoky Mountains since the final parts of the passes are generally steep and rocky. Around the point of difficulty change you'll come to the Narrow Canyon Trail; a good route to take, that is more gradual to the top. The last 5 miles are much more primitive than the first 6.\r\n\nThis is an amazing hike in the Idaho backcountry and you'll likely have the trail all to yourself, so be prepared!", "features": "Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 11.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [9089, 5100], "alt-change": [4064, 388], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 28.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7035243/deer-creek-trail-158", "title": "Deer Creek Trail (#158)", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.572889,-114.535621", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7035243", "info-text": {"description": "This canyon provides beautiful scenery and easy to moderate difficulty as you run through pine forests and along occasional rock cliffs towards the upper reaches of Deer Creek.  The big open views do not get extreme in any way, but you can connect to other trails that do open up the views more.  There are a few options that connect for significantly longer runs.  The trail is shared with motorcycles and mountain bikes, as well as equestrians.\r\n\nThe trail begins at the Deer Creek Trailhead, where Deer Creek Road terminates.  Travel almost 5 miles along Deer Creek, where the trail ends at the intersection of the Deer Creek Trail with the North Fork Deer Creek Trail (#157) and Lick Gulch Trail (#218).  Ascend roughly 1000 feet as you climb, mostly gently, up the canyon.  Continue your journey on another trail, or return on the same route back down Deer Creek.  There are a couple of creek crossings that may be difficult to get through without getting your feet wet.\r\n\nOne very excellent option, that skips the out-and-back, is to use the North Fork Deer Creek Road, North Fork Deer Creek Trail, and main fork of Deer Creek Trail to form a wonderful loop that is about 10.5 miles long.  This loop is not terribly steep either direction your run it, and takes in roughly 1300-1400 feet of ascending.  Run clockwise to climb more gently, or counter-clockwise to take in the steeper climbing on the uphill slopes of North Fork Deer Creek trail.  Park at the Deer Creek TH, or anywhere along the road between the fork for the North Fork Deer Creek Trail and the main trailhead.\r\n\nOther variations include starting up Deer Creek, but using the north end of the Wolftone-Curran (#160) trail, Kinsey Creek (#319), or the Kinsey-Curran Connector to connect other loops or run an out-and-back.  To create much longer running options, when the Deer Creek Trail ends, continue out the Lick Gulch trail to connect trails back to the Red Warrior trail and the North Fork of Deer Creek.\r\n\n(Notes: this description was completely rewritten by a trail runner in order to replace the old description that was copy/pasted in to populate content created by a mountain biker for the mountain biking site description.)", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 5.5, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [7030, 6074], "alt-change": [23, 979], "avg-grade": 3.0, "max-grade": 16.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7039812/upper-oregon-gulch-edge-of-the-world", "title": "Upper Oregon Gulch (Edge of the World)", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.750193,-114.504171", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7039812", "info-text": {"description": "Upper Oregon Gulch Trail, known locally as Edge of the World Trail, is not for the feint of heart. It starts off of Forest Service Road 168, and ascends incredibly steeply right from the gun. Shortly after, Edge of the World lives up to its namesake, and drops precipitously for the next three miles. Be ready for loose, rocky, and sometimes rooted terrain to follow you all the way down this beast of a descent.  \r\n\nIt's worth it however, as the views from this trail of the nearby Sawtooth Mountains are incredible. Don't get too distracted by these vistas and stay on the trail as it ducks in and out of the woods through the arid high country.\r\n\nThe final two sections of this trail should be approached with care as they are some of the steepest and most technical on the route. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7092515/goat-lake-trail", "title": "Goat Lake Trail", "difficulty": "Very Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.183537,-115.008422", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7092515", "info-text": {"description": "The trail is unmaintained and consists of a fairly well-beaten path with the occasional cairn that may or may not be the next vector point. Keep in mind that the straight line is not always the best way to the next cairn.\r\n\nThe trail starts off all innocent and cute on a ridge Northeast of Goat Lake while hiking the Alpine Way Trail. The path is actually quite nice as you head up the ridge to a couple of great photo opportunities. Be sure to take pictures of Goat Creek Falls, the tallest cascading waterfall in the Sawtooths. The trail will get tighter and the slope steeper as you come off the ridge to the south side but continue to climb. You find yourself right up under the most incredible sheer walls of rock. \r\n\nKeep working your way along the cairn as you steadily gain altitude while closing in on the top of the waterfall. At the top of the falls, cross over the creek being careful of slick surfaces and deadly drops. Almost up! Staying to the left of the creek, the trail comes alive with an actual path of sorts. Continue on over slightly better terrain to the lake. \r\n\nThere are tiny pockets in which to bed down here and there if you want to camp. The trail continues along the rocky east shore towards another slightly larger camp spot on the south end of the lake. Take a swim if you are familiar with the ice-cold water and the dangers it holds. Hypothermia can get you even in summer so limit your temp-sapping swim to a reasonable achievement. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7032350/weiser-river-national-recreation-trail", "title": "Weiser River National Recreation Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.986764,-116.36645", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7032350", "info-text": {"description": "Some would claim that the Idaho Centennial Trail is longer but they would be wrong as it is actually a collection of many smaller trails. This is not a set of trails or a system of smaller trails. This monster is 87.2 miles of hard pack road mix over old RR bed running from Tamarack, ID to Weiser, ID with small sections of paved trail in Council, Cambridge and Weaser. \r\n\nThis trail boasts two commercialized Hot Springs for your enjoyment along the way. An almost imperceptible grade gently aids your progress and when combined with a tailwind makes the hike almost too easy. There is an ongoing weed management program on this trail but it is Idaho after all.\r\n\nThere are a lot of well-placed bathrooms and water sources but be prepared for anything. Deer are commonly seen, but you may also see chukars, quail, ducks, geese, eagles, wild turkeys, blue herons, coyotes, bears, wolves, elk and mountain lions. Rainbow trout can be found in the Weiser River, too. \r\n\nThis trail is a great trail for family or group hikes as it has so many access points and photo opportunities. Keep in mind that most of the trail is bordered by private property and parts of the trail are still used by ranchers to access fields. Happy trails.\r\n\nIf you want to start even further up, use the West Pine Recreational Trail. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7027378/summit-flat-road", "title": "Summit Flat Road", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.93198,-115.669519", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7027378", "info-text": {"description": "Summit Flat Road is a winding, sloped trail with great views of the Boise forest. The views of the valley are spectacular, and the curves of highway 21 poking through the trees end a while after setting out, leaving you with a feeling of pleasant solitude. The trail is smooth and regular (especially when blanketed in snow in the winter) with the first four miles consisting of a moderate upward grade that is great for snowshoeing or skiing. Please be aware that this road is not closed to motor vehicles, and you may have to negotiate the trail with other users in both summer and winter, when the area is popular with snowmobilers.\r\n\nAbout three miles in, you'll arrive at the crux of a few different paths where you can continue on to different ridges via access roads. If you follow the ridge to the east (on the Pilot Peak Summit Spur), you'll find some places for backcountry camping with a beautiful view of the forest to the east. You won't want to miss the panoramic view at Pilot Peak at about 8,000 feet, which is incredible. There is a weather station that shares public information about conditions at the peak (MLLFI1).\r\n\nIf you make the turn-off to Pilot's Peak, make sure you have your bearings about you. It can get disorienting and if you start down the wrong way you could end up far from where you intend to be.\r\n\nYou'll be ascending about 2000' from the Moore's Creek Summit Trailhead, where the turnout from Highway 21 is. There is plenty of parking and pit toilets at the trailhead.\r\n\nFrom here, the rest of the trail is a long, and mellow descent all the way to where the road ends near Grimes Creek and Pioneer. With the exception of one other small rise between miles 9 and 11, you'll enjoy the gentle downhill. The trail meanders in and out of forested woods, and crossed meadows. Enjoy the lovely scenery along the way!", "features": "Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7028269/winter-is-one-of-the-best-times-to-experience-summit-flat-road", "ratings": {"rating": 3.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 19.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [7800, 4457], "alt-change": [2173, 3835], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 22.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7055621/big-burns-creek-trail-068", "title": "Big Burns Creek Trail #068", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.606099,-111.466356", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7055621", "info-text": {"description": "This is a great intermediate trail that starts with a nice, gradual 5.0-mile climb along the creek before the real climb up to the \"1000 Spring Valley.\" The trail meanders through nice small meadows, cottonwood groves, and rolls up and down through steeper parts of the canyon. At one point, the trail is completely overhung by a cliff for about 100 feet. All but one creek crossing has a bridge in place. \r\n\nThe trailhead is well marked as well as the rest of the trails along the route. This is a singletrack motorized trail so hiking in the dry months, you may run into other users, however, it is still a great hike close to Idaho Falls. There are other trails in the area for loop options if desired, like Old Ranger Trail #287, Hells Hole Trail #070, Coalmine Trail #064, and Little Burns Creek Trail #071.\r\n\nTo find the trail, follow the signs to Kelly Canyon Ski Resort off of Highway 26 out of Idaho Falls. Go past the resort at Heise (good pizza and cold beer for your way out). Where the road goes to the left to go to Kelly Canyon, stay right and head for the Wolf Creek parking area, this is a popular parking area to hike Sidewinder and Stinking Springs Canyon ATV Trail. Head past this parking area and keep driving up the Snake River and stay right at the next junction with Forest Road 217 (Table Rock Canyon) and continue up along the Snake River. \r\n\nOnce you hit a cattle guard that says \"No Trespass Burns Creek Ranch\" you are all most there. Then the climb eases a bit and you find Indian Meadows Trail #208 at the 5-mile mark.\r\n\nClimb another 0.5 mile to Graystone Butte at 6,649 feet before dropping down the ridge to a saddle and Gold Meadows Trail #260 at about the 7-mile mark.\r\n\nJust over the next rise you come to Sponge-Freezeout Trail #209 at 7.25 miles and Long Lake Trail #205 at 7.5 miles.\r\n\nClimb the ridge with views of Sponge Lake along the way and views of Long Lake, Eagle Mountain Lake and Round Lake from the top of Sponge Mountain at 7330 feet and about 10.5 miles in.\r\n\nDrop down to a saddle and start a traverse around Eagle Mountain. You'll cross into the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness on the side of Eagle Mountain at 11 miles.\r\n\nContinue the traverse to a saddle and the intersection of Boulder Creek Trail #211 at about 12.75 miles.\r\n\nAt about 13.75 miles End Butte 1 Trail #644 joins from the East.\r\n\nTraverse End Butte and follow the ridge before dropping down a secondary ridgeline between Wounded Doe Lake and Grotto one to meet up with Two Lakes Loop Trail #218 just above the upper lake at 17.75 miles.\r\n\nClimb back up to the main ridge and maintain it to the 20.5-mile point and the junction of Cliff Creek There are some short stretches of the trail that are steep, rocky, and/or boggy. Overall the trail is an amazing ridge hike that will take you from Deadwood Reservoir to Garden Valley. \r\n\nIn August 1986, the Lightning Creek drainage and the last few miles of trail near the west trailhead were the northern edge of the 18,500-acre Anderson Creek Fire.\r\n\nThe trail begins in a forest of lodgepole pine and Douglas-fir. The trail crosses Daisy Creek about 1.5 miles in then parallels Trail Creek for about 3-miles before ascending steeply to Lightning Ridge. The ridge offers great views of the surrounding mountains. The trail then descends steeply to Onion Valley, crosses Onion Creek and then soon afterward intersects with the Onion Valley Trail. Another climb leads to views of Scott Mountain and its lookout. Then you'll pass through the area burned by the Anderson Creek Fire. Finally, follow the ridge for several miles and then descend to FS 611.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7070408/some-neat-rock-formations-at-another-viewpoint", "ratings": {"rating": 2.7, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 15.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [7560, 4564], "alt-change": [2795, 3720], "avg-grade": 8.0, "max-grade": 73.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7040078/sweet-n-low", "title": "Sweet 'n Low", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.413517,-114.335009", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7040078", "info-text": {"description": "This trail is mostly beginner level with a few small sections that either get a little steeper or have a couple of minor obstacles. The trail starts alongside a good dirt road and proceeds up a road suitable for OHV's but little else. After about 200 yards, you begin to start seeing the potholes that were formed when the channel made a whirlpool around the surrounding basalt cliffs, turning large boulders of basalt lava around the bottom where they were ground down to dust and carried away. What is left is varying stages of this event. In reality, it is composed of 3 remaining hikeable sections with miles of highway, forest service roads and farm roads connecting the three. As of Nov 2017, these 3 sections will provide you with 78.4 miles of \"Rail Trail\". \r\n\nYou can expect beautiful wooded areas on the northern end and waves farmland and a few tressels on the Sothern end of the Rail Trail. You can also expect to enjoy an ever-changing view of the Teton Mountain Range. \r\n\nThe Oregon Pacific Rail lines were established to provide tourist access to the Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks in 1908 and 1913. \r\n\nThe hiking surface is dirt and gravel but obviously, maintain easy RR grades throughout. \r\n\nTHIS SECTION:\r\nWhat can we say? Loads of farmland....\r\nTrestles at 3.6 mi, 6.3 mi, and 19.4 mi. If you are afraid of heights just stay in the center. There are great views at each.
